{{refimprove|date=July 2016}} The '''Imperial Standards of Iran''' were the personal official flags of the [[Shāhanshāh]], [[Shahbānū]], and Crown Prince of Iran, adopted at the beginning of 1971.
The official flag of Shāhanshāh consisted of a pale-blue field with the [[flag of Iran]] in the upper left corner and the Pahlavi coat of arms in the centre. At the top of the coat of arms was the Pahlavi crown, created for the Coronation of [[Rezā Shāh of Iran|Rezā Shāh]] in 1926. The Imperial motto of Pahlavi is "''Mara dad farmud va Khod Davar Ast''" ("Justice He bids me do, as He will judge me" or, alternatively, "He gave me power to command, and He is the judge").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fotw.net/flags/ir_imp-i.html|title=Iranian Empire (Pahlavi dynasty): Imperial standards|accessdate=2007-05-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070412122220/http://fotw.net/flags/ir_imp-i.html|archivedate=2007-04-12|df=}}</ref>
[[Pale blue]] was the colour of the Imperial Family. The uniforms of the Imperial Guard included this colour to show their allegiance.

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Lambeth slavery case | location = [[Lambeth]], [[South London]], [[England]] | date = {{spaced ndash}}25 October 2013 | time = | timezone = | coordinates = | type = [[Slavery]], [[domestic servitude]] | victims = {{Plainlist| * Aishah Wahab<ref name="Sawer">Patrick Sawer, et al [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/10486213/How-Chairman-Mao-of-Brixton-built-his-sect-of-slaves.html "How Chairman Mao of Brixton built his sect of 'slaves’"], telegraph.co.uk, 2013</ref> * Josephine Herivel<ref>Martin Evans, et al [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10476943/Irish-slave-revealed-as-daughter-of-Bletchley-Park-code-breaking-hero.html "Irish 'slave' revealed as daughter of Bletchley Park code breaking hero "], telegraph.co.uk, 26 November 2013</ref> * Rosie Morgan-Davies<ref name="Sawer"/>
}} | susperps = {{Plainlist| * Aravindan Balakrishnan * Chanda Balakrishnan }} }} On 21 November 2013 [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] from the [[National Crime Agency#Organisational Structure|Human Trafficking Unit]] arrested two suspects at a residential address in [[Lambeth]], [[South London]]. A 73-year-old ethnic Indian [[Singaporean]] man, Aravindan Balakrishnan, and a 67-year-old [[Tanzanian]]<ref name = "growing up"/> woman, his wife, Chanda Pattni, had been investigated for [[slavery]] and [[domestic servitude]].<ref name="Halliday"/><ref name="Standard"/> The case centred around the [[Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought]] commune which was led by Balakrishnan. In the early 1980s after a police raid, Balakrishnan decided to move the group's activities underground. Balakrishnan's control over his followers intensified and the commune became a prison to his followers. On 25 October 2013, three women were rescued from the commune. These were: a 69-year-old [[Malaysians in the United Kingdom|Malaysian]] woman (later revealed to be Aishah Wahab),<ref name="Sawer"/> a 57-year-old [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] woman (Josephine Herivel) and a 30-year-old [[United Kingdom|British]] woman (Katy Morgan-Davies).<ref name="Standard">{{cite news |title=Women victims 'held for 30 years' |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/panewsfeeds/women-victims-held-for-30-years-8954976.html |publisher=London Evening Standard |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 }}</ref> Katy Morgan-Davies was born into the sect and hadn't experienced the outside world until her release.
==Perpetrator== '''Aravindan Balakrishnan''' (known to his followers as "'''Comrade Bala'''") was born in [[Kerala]], [[India]] but migrated to [[Singapore]], [[British Malaya|Malaya]], where his father was a soldier, when he was 10.<ref name="Ward-Tele">{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Victoria|title=Aravindan Balakrishnan: the Maoist cult leader who used brutal violence and rape to strip women of their dignity|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/12031312/Aravindan-Balakrishnan-the-Maoist-cult-leader-who-used-brutal-violence-and-rape-to-strip-women-of-their-dignity.html|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=4 December 2015}}</ref> Balakrishnan was a student at [[Raffles Institution]] and later the [[University of Singapore]], where although gaining a reputation as a "quiet chap",<ref name="Reuters-AO">{{cite news|author1=Reuters|title=UK Maoist cult leader raped followers, enslaved daughter|url=http://www.asiaone.com/world/uk-maoist-cult-leader-raped-followers-enslaved-daughter|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=AsiaOne|date=13 November 2015}}</ref> he became increasingly politically active and believed that he would have been imprisoned in Singapore had he openly admitted to being a [[communist]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> In 1977, while living in London, His Singaporean citizenship – which he gained in 1960 – was revoked due to his leadership of the [[Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought]], which the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Singapore)|Ministry of Home Affairs]] accused of engaging in "activities which are prejudicial to the security" of Singapore, and denounced him as a radical "closely associated with [[Eurocommunists]]".<ref name="Reuters-AO" /> The authorities claimed that Balakrishnan and others, many of them former Singaporean students he had associated with in London, were plotting to overthrow Singapore's leader, [[Lee Kuan Yew]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" />
Despite believing the United Kingdom to be a [[fascist state]] due to its treatment of the people of Singapore during the [[Malayan Emergency]], Balakrishnan emigrated to the UK in 1963 on a [[British Council]] scholarship to study at the [[London School of Economics]], and married his wife Chandra in 1971.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> Over the years he built up a following by giving lectures and staging various [[sit-in]]s and protests. He was a regular attendee at [[London]] demonstrations, where he waved banners depicting the Chinese leader [[Mao Zedong]] and addressed the crowds.<ref name="Ward-Tele" />
In 1974, Balakrishnan and his "small clique" were expelled from the [[Communist Party of England (Marxist–Leninist)]] on account of "their pursuance of conspiratorial and [[wikt:splittist|splittist]] activities ... spreading [[social fascist]] slanders against the Party and the proletarian movement" and attempting "to put themselves above the discipline of the Party".<ref name="CPE(M-L) statement">[http://www.marxists.org/history/erol/uk.hightide/cpestatements.htm "Statements of the National Executive Committee, CPE (ML)"], ''The Marxist-Leninist'', 1:1, September 1974, reprinted at marxists.org. Quoted in Nick Cohen [http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/nick-cohen/2013/11/cultists-communists-too-close-to-us-for-comfort/ "Cultists & communists – too close to us for comfort"], ''The Spectator'' (blog), 25 November 2013</ref> The CPE(M–L) "repudiated the metaphysical logic harmfully promoted" by Balakrishnan in "opposition to dialectical materialism and the concrete analysis of concrete conditions".<ref name="CPE(M-L) statement"/> In response, Balakrishnan set up the Workers' Institute and launched his own publication, the ''South London Workers' Bulletin'', which accused the CPE(M–L) of being "fascists" and "agents of imperialism".<ref name="Ford-WW-989">{{cite news|last1=Ford|first1=Eddie|title=Maoist 'slaves': Combating the fascist state in Brixton - Weekly Worker|url=http://weeklyworker.co.uk/worker/989/maoist-slaves-combating-the-fascist-state-in-brixt/|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=Weekly Worker|issue=989|date=5 December 2013}}</ref>
Between 1974 and 1976, his followers attempted to "build revolutionary stable base areas in working-class communities",<ref name="On Building a">{{cite news|author1=Workers’ Institute of Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought|title=On Building a Revolutionary Stable Base Area|url=https://www.marxists.org/history/erol/uk.hightide/stable-base.htm|work=Encyclopedia of Anti-Revisionism On-Line|year=1977}}</ref> primarily [[South London]], and worked in ordinary jobs. Balakrishnan discouraged his followers from joining [[trade unions]], describing them as agents of the "imperialist fascist bourgeoisie".<ref name="Smith-Conv">{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Evan|title=Inside the paranoid Maoist cults of 1970s Britain|url=http://theconversation.com/inside-the-paranoid-maoist-cults-of-1970s-britain-20739|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Conversation|date=28 November 2013}}</ref>
Eventually, after the more liberal members of his group drifted away, a cult of around 10 female members formed around him. The collective moved to Brixton in 1976, under the title [[Workers Institute of Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> Following [[Mao Zedong#Death and aftermath|Mao's death in 1976]], the Institute built the Mao Zedong Memorial Centre at 140 Acre Lane, [[Brixton]], which also functioned as a communist collective of "thirteen comrades", with "13 members living on the premises, half in paid work, six doing full-time revolutionary work, with a strong emphasis on women taking a leading role (apart from leading the Party Committee headed by Bala)".<ref name="On Building a" /><ref name="Smith-Conv" /><ref>{{cite news|title=High Tide: The Consolidation of Maoism by the Late 1970’s|url=https://www.marxists.org/history/erol/uk.hightide/|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=Encyclopedia of Anti-Revisionism On-Line}}</ref> Members were handed a rota of chores and only allowed to go out in pairs, which Balakrishnan claimed was because the area they lived in was "notorious for violence" and "anything could happen".<ref name="Ward-Tele" /><ref name="Ward-Tele2">{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Victoria|title=Maoist 'cult' leader denies rape as he claims female commune members competed for his affections|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/12019410/Maoist-cult-leader-denies-rape-as-he-claims-female-commune-members-competed-for-his-affections.html|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=Telegraph|date=26 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>
Following a police raid on the Memorial Centre in March 1978, which the group claimed involved "over 200 police", including officers from the [[Special Patrol Group]], "under the pretext of searching for drugs", the Workers' Institute effectively went underground, with the remaining members being convinced to end all contact with others and maintain an intense level of secrecy.<ref name="Smith-Conv" /> Family members were later branded fascist agents and ostracised,<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> and Balakrishnan and his captives moved to a number of properties during this time as a means for him to escape detection from the authorities.<ref name="Smith-Conv" /> Balakrishnan convinced his followers that everything was controlled by him from the sun, the moon, wind and fires; that he could overthrow governments, control natural disasters, and make people live or die.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> In order to progress his cause, Balakrishnan invented "JACKIE" (an acronym for [[Jehovah]], [[Allah]], [[Christ]], [[Krishna]] and [[Eknath Easwaran|Immortal Easwaran]]) – a type of dangerous, mystical machine that monitored all thought and could control minds.<ref name="Cooke">{{cite news|last1=Cooke|first1=Rachel|title=My 30 years as prisoner of a London cult|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/jan/22/katy-morgan-davies-interview-balakrishnan-cult-brixton-survivor|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Guardian|date=22 January 2017}}</ref>
Balakrishnan began sexually abusing two of the women in 1979, often physically beating them and making others watch as he did so. All of the women were beaten and four (not including his wife) were said to have been sexually assaulted or engaged with sexual relations with him.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> Balakrishnan forced the women to swallow his ejaculate as it was "the elixir of life", and claimed the women he sexually abused had been trying to seduce him out of "jealousy" for his lover.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /><ref name="Ward-Tele2" />
==Victims== *[[Katy Morgan-Davies]] - born in 1983, she was originally named Prem Maopinduzi Davies. She began calling herself "Rosie" in her teens. She has subsequently changed her name to Katy Morgan-Davies, after the American singer [[Katy Perry]]. She is the biological daughter of Balakrishnan and Sian Davies.<ref name = "growing up">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-b0af7ef5-1031-4e1f-a3ac-b3c21ef0f932|title=Growing up a prisoner in a cult|date=26 January 2017|accessdate=28 January 2017|author=Vanessa Engle|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Morgan-Davies was brought up entirely isolated from the outside world and never went to a nursery, school, dentist or doctor. She was not told who her parents were. The commune members taught her to read and write.<ref name=bbc2>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-b0af7ef5-1031-4e1f-a3ac-b3c21ef0f932</ref>
*[[Sian Davies]] - in the early 1980s, after joining the commune, she had a sexual relationship with Balakrishnan. On Christmas Eve 1996, Morgan-Davies remembered seeing Davies bound and gagged on the living room for trying to escape. Later, she fell out of a top floor bathroom window and was taken to hospital. In hospital she suffered a rapid decline in her mental health and fell into a coma. She died eight months later. After the fall, her family were told she had gone to India to do charity work.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} At the time of Davie's death her daughter, Morgan-Davies, did not know she was her mother.
*[[Aishah Wahab]] - a [[Malaysians|Malaysian]] woman who moved to the United Kingdom at the age of 24 to study, joining the group shortly after.<ref name = "growing up"/> Aishah was reportedly so drawn in by Balakrishnan's Marxist rhetoric that she left her fiancé and moved in with the collective.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
*[[Oh Kar Eng]] - nurse from [[Malaysia]] who had followed Balakrishnan from the 1970s. She hit her head on a cupboard in 2001 and suffered a stroke. No medical treatment was allowed by the commune and she died the next day.{{r|bbc}} The police were not informed of the accident. Her family were not told about her cremation, and they were told the commune did not have their ashes when in fact they were in a lockup garage in West Norwood.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
*[[Josephine Herivel]] - known as Josie, was a violinist studying at the [[Royal College of Music]] before she joined the group.<ref name = "growing up"/> Her father, [[John Herivel]] was one of the [[Bletchley Park]] [[codebreakers]] who helped Britain and its allies win [[World War II]]. She is believed to have moved to London in the 1970s and disowned her family after becoming involved with the Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} Herivel initiated the escape plan after becoming concerned with Morgan-Davies rapid weight loss (which was due to undiagnosed diabetes). Medical treatment was not permitted by the commune. Herivel secretly phoned a helpline after memorizing the number from a television program. Herivel has denounced the Balakrishnan sentencing, claiming he has been framed by the state.{{r|bbc}}
==Imprisonment and rescue== The two older victims are believed to have met Balakrishnan in [[London]] through, according to police, a shared political ideology,<ref name="Evans">Martin Evans [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10472632/Slavery-case-suspects-named-as-former-Maoist-collective-leaders.html "Slavery case: suspects named as former Maoist collective leaders"], telegraph.co.uk, 25 November 2013</ref> as he was the leader of the [[Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought]].<ref>[http://www.channel4.com/news/slave-house-couple-lambeth-leaders-1970s-political-cult 'Slave' house couple 'leaders of 1970s political cult'"], ''[[Channel 4 News]]'', 25 November 2013</ref> The women were not being physically restrained, but held by "invisible handcuffs" after being subjected to [[Mind control|brainwashing]], [[Psychological abuse|emotional abuse]] and [[physical abuse]] by their captors.<ref name="Standard_2">{{cite news |title=London slave women endured 30 years of beatings, brainwashing and emotional control |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/crime/london-slave-women-endured-30-years-of-beatings-brainwashing-and-emotional-control-8956001.html |publisher=London Evening Standard |date=22 November 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |first=Justin |last=Davenport}}</ref> The three women, who are not related, are said to have been held captive for more than 30 years with the youngest of the three thought to have spent her whole life in servitude.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |title=Women 'held as slaves for 30 years' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-25040741 |publisher=BBC News |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 }}</ref> However it has not yet been established if she was born in the house from where she was rescued.<ref name="BBC"/> The police were tipped off by [[Freedom Charity]] who contacted police following a phone call they had received on 18 October, during which a woman stated that she'd been held unwillingly for more than 30 years.<ref name="Standard_2"/><ref name="Irish">{{cite news |title=Irishwoman raises alarm after being held captive ‘for decades’ in south London home |url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/irishwoman-raises-alarm-after-being-held-captive-for-decades-in-south-london-home-29773908.html |work=[[Irish Independent]] |publisher=Independent News & Media |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 }}</ref> [[Aneeta Prem]] of Freedom Charity confirmed that the Irish woman made contact with the charity after watching the [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] television documentary ''Forced to Marry'' about [[forced marriage]] in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Irish"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Lambeth 'slaves rescue': Woman 'called Freedom Charity after watching TV documentary on forced marriage' |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/lambeth-slaves-rescue-woman-called-2836476 |work=Daily Mirror |publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=23 November 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |first=James |last=Robertson |first2=Mark |last2=Jefferies }}</ref> The women, who are said to be "highly traumatised", are now in safe accommodation.<ref name="BBC"/>
The two suspects were bailed until April 2014,<ref name="Shaw">Danny Shaw [https://twitter.com/DannyShawBBC/status/425657327706861568] twitter.com, 21 January 2014</ref> and were unable to return to the three-bedroom flat they rented from a housing association.<ref name="Evans"/>
On 11 December 2014, it emerged that Balakrishnan had been charged with offences relating to cruelty to a person under 16, four counts of rape and 17 counts of indecent assault. Balakrishnan appeared before Westminster magistrates on 17 December 2014.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-30431988 "Man charged in London 'slavery' inquiry"], BBC News, 11 December 2014</ref> His wife, Chanda Pattni, was released earlier in 2014, as there was considered to be insufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction.<ref>Josh Halliday [https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/dec/11/london-slavery-case-cps-charges-ravindan-alakrishnan "London ‘slavery’ case: CPS charges Aravindan Balakrishnan"], ''The Guardian'', 11 December 2014</ref>
Balakrishnan's trial started on 11 November 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/11990783/Maoist-cult-leader-kept-daughter-as-slave-in-south-London-for-30-years-court-hears.html |title=Maoist cult leader sexually assaulted followers and kept daughter as slave for 30 years, court hears |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date= 12 November 2015 |author=Gordon Rayner |accessdate= 26 November 2015}}</ref> During his trial, he acted as the only defence witness, and told jurors that a challenge to his leadership resulted in the 1986 [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster]], and that JACKIE was responsible for the death of a Malaysian prime minister and the election of [[Jeremy Corbyn]] as [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Leader of the Labour Party]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" />
On 4 December 2015, Balakrishnan was convicted of child cruelty, false imprisonment, four counts of rape, six counts of indecent assault and two counts of assault.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/dec/04/commune-leader-aravindan-balakrishnan-guilty-of-child-cruelty "Maoist cult leader guilty of child cruelty and sexual assaults"], ''The Guardian'', 4 December 2015</ref> On 29 January 2016, Balakrishnan was jailed for 23 years. <ref>{{Cite web|title = Maoist cult leader Aravindan Balakrishnan jailed for 23 years - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-35443423|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-01-29|language = en-GB}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=bbc>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-b0af7ef5-1031-4e1f-a3ac-b3c21ef0f932</ref>
<ref name="Halliday">{{cite news |title=Three women rescued after 'decades of slavery' in south London home |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/21/women-rescued-decades-slavery-south-london |publisher=The Guardian |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 |first=Josh |last=Halliday |first2=Peter |last2=Walker}}</ref> }}

This is a '''list of people and organisations named in the [[Paradise Papers]]''' as connected to offshore companies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Explore The Politicians in the Paradise Papers|url=https://www.icij.org/investigations/paradise-papers/explore-politicians-paradise-papers/|publisher=International Consortium of Investigative Journalists|accessdate=5 November 2017|date=5 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171106011937/https://www.icij.org/investigations/paradise-papers/explore-politicians-paradise-papers/|archivedate=6 November 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> International Consortium of Investigative Journalists had stated in their politicians database as disclaimer, that "There are legitimate uses for offshore companies and trusts. We do not intend to suggest or imply that any people, companies or other entities included in the ICIJ Offshore Leaks Database have broken the law or otherwise acted improperly. "

<!-- Please do not remove or change this AfD message until the discussion has been closed. --> {{Article for deletion/dated|page=List of people saved by Oskar Schindler|timestamp=20181124061300|year=2018|month=November|day=24|substed=yes|help=off}} <!-- Once discussion is closed, please place on talk page: {{Old AfD multi|page=List of people saved by Oskar Schindler|date=24 November 2018|result='''keep'''}} --> <!-- End of AfD message, feel free to edit beyond this point --> {{short description|List of people saved by Oskar Schindler during the Holocaust}}
Approximately 1,200 persons were saved by [[Oskar Schindler]] during the [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]]. They survived the years of Nazi regime primarily through the intervention of Schindler who found them protected status as industrial workers at his [[Oskar Schindler's Enamel Factory|enamelware factory]] in [[Kraków]] and, after 1944, at an [[Brünnlitz labor camp|armaments factory]] in [[Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia|occupied Czechoslovakia]]. There, they avoided being sent to [[Extermination camp|death camps]] and survived the war. Schindler expended his personal fortune as an industrialist to save the Schindlerjuden.
Their story has been depicted in the book ''[[Schindler's Ark]]'', by [[Thomas Keneally]], and [[Steven Spielberg]]'s film adaptation of the novel, ''[[Schindler's List]]''. [[Poldek Pfefferberg]], one of the survivors, persuaded Thomas Keneally to write the novel and Steven Spielberg to produce the film.
In 2012, more than 8,500 descendants of people saved by Oskar Schindler lived in the [[United States]], [[Europe]], and [[Israel]].<ref>[http://www.tribune242.com/news/2012/mar/28/survivor-of-the-holocaust-tells-how-schindler/ Survivor Of The Holocaust Tells How Schindler Saved Her Life] http://www.tribune242.com. Retrieved 3 November 2014.</ref>
==The List== The original list of people who were transported to [[Brünnlitz labor camp|Schindler's Brünnlitz factory]] in [[Brněnec]] ([[Sudetenland|Sudetengau]]) was prepared by [[Mietek Pemper]], [[Itzhak Stern]] and Oskar Schindler<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news |title=Mietek Pemper |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/8578020/Mietek-Pemper.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BjJNDD9m?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/8578020/Mietek-Pemper.html |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |date={{date|2011-6-11|mdy}} |archivedate=2012-10-27 |accessdate={{date|2012-10-27|mdy}} |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=mg>{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Oskar Schindler's collaborator, Mietek Pemper, has died |url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/entertainment/movie-guide/Oskar+Schindler+collaborator+dies/4919305/story.html |work=[[Agence France-Presse]] |publisher=[[The Gazette (Montreal)]] |date=2011-06-15 |accessdate=2011-06-26}}{{dead link|date=October 2012}}</ref><ref name=nytimes>{{cite news |first=Douglas |last=Martin |title=Mietek Pemper, 91, Camp Inmate Who Compiled Schindler's List |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/19/world/europe/19pemper.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110621040823/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/19/world/europe/19pemper.html?_r=1 |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=18 June 2011 |archivedate=2011-06-21 |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> during September and October of 1944. That list probably no longer exists.
Another list with 1,000 names, compiled by former camp stenographer Mietek Pemper upon the prisoners' arrival 21 October 1944 at Schindler's Brünnlitz factory, was presented by Pemper to the [[International Tracing Service]] in 1958.<ref>[http://www.its-arolsen.org/en/help_and_faq/sample_documents/index.html#c2713 Sample Documents from the ITS Archives] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721233447/http://www.its-arolsen.org/en/help_and_faq/sample_documents/index.html |date=2011-07-21}}, [[International Tracing Service]]</ref>
Two lists of 1,098 prisoners made by camp administration in Brünnlitz on 18 April 1945 are extant,<ref name=list>[http://www.oskarschindler.com/list.htm Schindler's list on www.oskarschindler.com]</ref> and are preserved in [[Yad Vashem]] Memorial, where Oskar and Emilie Schindler are recognized among [[Righteous Among the Nations|the Righteous]].<ref name=Righteous>[http://www.yadvashem.org/righteous/stories/schindler Schindlers Oskar and Emilie Schindler in The Righteous Among The Nations]</ref> The first list contains 297 female prisoners while the second list contains 801 male prisoners. There are several preserved copies and carbon copies of the list from April 1945, with some in museums while others are in private hands (mostly of families of former prisoners). In April 2009 a carbon copy of the original list, documenting 801 names, was discovered among the documentation author Thomas Keneally had donated to the [[State Library of New South Wales]] in [[Sydney]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2009/04/08/index.php?section=espectaculos&article=a09n2esp|title=Hallan la lista de Schindler|author=Reuters|first=|date=8 April 2009|website=|publisher=[[La Jornada]]|language=es|trans-title=Finding Schindler's List|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=6 May 2018}}</ref>

Abbreviation "ang" stands for "angelernt", meaning "semi-skilled"; the person was trained on the job but did not complete a formal apprenticeship.
==Biographies and related material == *[[Joseph Bau|Bau, Joseph]]. ''Dear God, Have You Ever Gone Hungry?'' Arcade Publishing, 1998. ''-'' A memoir by Schindler survivor Joseph Bau about some of his experiences during the Holocaust, being rescued by Schindler, and the impact of these experiences after the war. *Brecher, Elinor J. ''Schindler's Legacy: True Stories of the List Survivors.'' New York: Dutton, 1994. (D 811 .A2 B74 1994) - A compilation of interviews with many of those saved by Schindler. Includes reports of their experiences in the concentration camps and with Schindler, and their stories of life after the war. Includes over one hundred personal photographs. *Byers, Ann. ''Oskar Schindler: Saving Jews from the Holocaust.'' Berkeley Heights, NJ: Enslow, 2005. (D 804.66 .S38 B94 2005) - Biography of Schindler, with emphasis on his rescue activities during the war. Part of the "Holocaust Heroes and Nazi Criminals" series for young adult readers. Includes glossary and index. *[[David M. Crowe|Crowe, David M.]] ''Oskar Schindler: The Untold Account of His Life, Wartime Activities, and the True Story Behind the List.'' Boulder, CO: Westview Press, 2004. (D 804.66 .S38 C76 2004) - A comprehensive account of Schindler's early life, business career, rescue attempts, and postwar experiences in Germany and Argentina. Based on personal interviews and archival sources, including Schindler's personal papers discovered in 1997. Includes extensive bibliography and index. * Fensch, Thomas, editor. ''Oskar Schindler and His List: The Man, the Book, the Film, the Holocaust and its Survivors.'' Forest Dale, VT: Paul S. Eriksson, 1995. - A collection of essays, articles, and interviews which illuminate Schindler and the international effect of his story. Includes a reprint of an article written about Schindler in 1949 and sections about Thomas Keneally's book Schindler's List, Steven Spielberg's film adaptation of the story, and issues and implications of the Holocaust. * Fogelman, Eva. ''Conscience & Courage: Rescuers of Jews During the Holocaust.'' New York: Doubleday, 1994. (D 810 .R4 F64 1994) - Relates stories about Schindler and his efforts to save Jews in the context of other rescue efforts and courageous acts during the Holocaust. Examines the motivation of Schindler and other rescuers, including personal, psychological, and historical factors. * Gruntová, Jitka: ''Legendy a fakta o Oskaru Schindlerovi.'' Praha, 2002. - Comprehensive account of Schindler's life, creation of the famous list and the daily reality of the life in the Brünnlitz factory. Based on interviews, books and archival sources. *[[Laura Hillman|Hillman, Laura]]. ''i will plant you a lilac tree – a memoir of a Schindler's list survivor.'' Simon and Schuster, 2006. The story of a Schindler's List survivor, her family, and her relationship with fellow inmate Dick Hillman in various concentration and labor camps during the Holocaust. *[[Thomas Keneally|Keneally, Thomas]]. ''[[Schindler's Ark]].'' New York: Simon and Schuster, 1982. (PR 9619.3 .K46 S3 1982) - A fictional recreation of the story of Oskar Schindler, an industrialist who saved 1,100 Jews from death by employing them in his factory in Kraków. Drawn from authentic records, the testimony of many of those saved by Schindler, and the author's extensive research. Also published as Schindler's Ark. *Keneally, Thomas. ''Searching for Schindler: A memoir.'' 2008 - A memoir by the author of ''Schindler's Ark'' about the process of writing the novel, and the movie based on the novel that followed. Includes the stories of Schindler survivors, especially focusing on [[Poldek Pfefferberg|Leopold "Poldek" Pfefferberg]]. *[[Leon Leyson|Leyson, Leon]]. ''The Boy on the Wooden Box: How the Impossible Became Possible . . . on Schindler's List.'' Atheneum Books for Young Readers, 2015. - A memoir by one of the youngest Schindler survivors, who had to stand on a wooden box to operate factory machinery. Intended for young readers. * Meltzer, Milton. ''"Schindler's Jews." In Rescue: The Story of How Gentiles Saved Jews in the Holocaust'', 55-67. New York: Harper & Row, 1988. (D 810 .R4 M247 1988) - A brief, personal account of Schindler's life and heroism. Written for young adults. *Müller-Madej, Stella. ''A Girl From Schindler's List''. - A autobiography by a young Schindler survivor and her family, from Kraków to Brünnlitz. * Roberts, Jack L. ''Oskar Schindler. San Diego: Lucent Books,'' 1996. (D 804.66 .S38 R628 1996) - Interweaves the biography of Oskar Schindler with the larger events of the Holocaust, including the rise of anti-Semitism and the implementation of the "[[Final Solution]]." Briefly discusses Schindler's life after the war. Includes photographs. Written for young adults. *[[Robin O'Neil|O'Neil, Robin]]. ''Oskar Schindler: Stepping Stone to Life'', Susaneking.com, 2010 - A biography focusing on Oskar Schindler's rescue activity during the Holocaust, based on published and unpublished materials and eyewitness interviews conducted on and off by the author since 1987. *[[Mietek Pemper|Pemper, Mieczysław]]. ''The Road to Rescue: The Untold Story of Schindler's List''. Other Press, 2011. - A Schindler survivor's personal account of his activities during the Holocaust, including his forced employment by [[Amon Göth]], including the assistance he provided to Schindler in his rescue operations, and his testifying against Göth in his war crime trial after the end of the war. *[[Emilie Schindler|Schindler, Emilie]]. ''Where Light and Shadow Meet: A Memoir.'' New York: Norton, 1997. (D 811.5 .S31513 1997) - An autobiography by Oskar Schindler's wife, written with the help of [[Erika Rosenberg]]. Tells her story from childhood to after the war. Presents a detailed, behind-the-scenes account of the list's development and the steps taken to save Jews. Includes numerous photos and two maps. * Silver, Eric. ''"The Few Who Disobeyed." In The Book of the Just: The Unsung Heroes Who Rescued Jews from Hitler,'' 147-154. New York: Grove Press, 1994. (D 804.65 .S55 1992) - Uses personal testimony and historical documents to construct a more personal picture of Schindler and to describe the great lengths he took to save Jews by employing them in his factory and bargaining for their lives. * Skotnicki, Aleksander B. ''Oskar Schindler in the Eyes of Cracovian Jews Rescued by Him.'' Kraków: Wydawn. AA, 2008. (D 804.66 .S38 S5813 2008) - Examines Schindler's legacy through testimony gathered from the Polish Jews saved by his efforts. Contains articles discussing Schindler, the list, and Płaszów concentration camp and the enamelware factory. A short list of films, press reports, and books is also presented, along with numerous photos from a variety of sources. * Zuckerman, Abraham. ''A Voice in the Chorus: Memories of a Teenager Saved by Schindler.'' Stamford, CT: Longmeadow Press, 1994. (D 804.3 .Z84 1994) - A survivor's personal narrative describing his life in Kraków before the war, his imprisonment in concentration camps, and his rescue by Oskar Schindler. Also tells of his life after the war. Includes personal photographs. Previously published as A Voice in the Chorus: Life as a Teenager in the Holocaust.

page.title: List of personal coats of arms of Vice Presidents of the United States

revision.comment: /* See also */Added content
revision.text:
Several [[United States]] [[Vice President of the United States|vice presidents]] have borne a [[coat of arms]]; largely through inheritance, assumption, or grants from foreign [[heraldic authority|heraldic authorities]].
==Arms of the Vice Presidents== {| class=wikitable |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center;" ! style="width:206px;"| Arms ! Name of Vice President and Blazon |- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of John Adams.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[John Adams]], 1st Vice President, 1789–1797:
'''Shield:''' Gules six crosses-crosslet fitchy Argent, on a chief Or three pellets, the center one charged with a fleur-de-lys and the other two with lions passant guardant Argent.
'''Crest:''' A Lion passant holding in his dexter paw a cross-crosslet fitchy Argent.
'''Motto:''' ''Libertatem amicitiam retinebis et fidem'' (Freedom, friendship and fidelity).<ref name="Signers of the Declaration">[http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=Notable.Declaration Signers of the Declaration of Independence] American Heraldry Society's Website</ref>
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Thomas Jefferson.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Thomas Jefferson]], 2nd Vice President, 1797–1801:
'''Shield:''' Azure a fret and on a chief Gules three leopards' faces Argent
'''Crest:''' A lion's head erased Or.
'''Motto:''' ''Ab eo libertas a quo spiritus'' (The one who gives life gives liberty).<ref name="Signers of the Declaration" />
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Aaron Burr]], 3rd Vice President, 1801–1805:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of George Clinton.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[George Clinton (vice president)|George Clinton]], 4th Vice President, 1805–1812:
'''Shield:''' Argent, six cross crosslets fitchy Sable on a chief Azure two mullets Or pierced Gules
'''Crest:''' Out of a ducal coronet Gules a plume of five ostrich feathers Argent banded by a ribbon Azure
'''Motto:''' ''Cara patria, carior libertas'' (Dear fatherland, dearer freedom)
|- valign=top |align=center | |[[Elbridge Gerry]], 5th Vice President, 1813–1814:
No arms known
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Daniel D. Tompkins.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Daniel D. Tompkins]], 6th Vice President, 1817–1825:
'''Shield:''' Azure, on a chevron between three cock-pheasants close Or three cross-crosslets Sable
'''Crest:''' A unicorn's head, erased, per fess, Argent and Or, armed and maned, counterchanged, gorged with a chaplet of laurel, Vert.
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of John C. Calhoun.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[John C. Calhoun]], 7th Vice President, 1825–1832:
'''Shield:''' Argent, a saltire engrailed Sable
'''Crest:''' A hart's head couped Gules attired Argent
'''Supporters:''' Two ratch-hounds Argent, collared Sable
'''Motto:''' ''Si je puis'' (If I may)
|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Martin Van Buren.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Martin van Buren]], 8th Vice President, 1833–1837:
'''Shield:''' Per pale, Or a greyhound rampant contourny Gules, and Gules two bars embattled-counterembattled Or
'''Crest:''' A greyhound rampant between the wings of a vol Gules and Or.<ref>[http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.VanBuren The Arms of Martin Van Buren] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321032529/http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.VanBuren |date=2012-03-21 }} American Heraldry Society's Website</ref>

No arms known

No arms known

No arms known

|- valign=top |align=center | |[[William A. Wheeler]], 19th Vice President, 1877–1881:

|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Chester A. Arthur.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Chester A. Arthur]], 20th Vice President, 1881:
'''Shield:''' Gules a chevron Argent between three rests (clarions) Or.
'''Crest:''' A falcon rising proper belled and jessed Or.
'''Motto:''' ''Impelle obstantia'' (Thrust aside obstacles).<ref>[http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.Arthur The Arms Used by Chester A. Arthur] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218032644/http://www.americanheraldry.org/pages/index.php?n=President.Arthur |date=2015-02-18 }} American Heraldry Society's Website</ref>

|- valign=top |align=center| [[File:Coat of Arms of Theodore Roosevelt.svg|100px]] |Arms of [[Theodore Roosevelt]], 25th Vice President, 1901:
'''Shield:''' Argent upon a grassy mound a rose bush proper bearing three roses Gules barbed and seeded proper

{{Infobox person |name = Margaret Ann Neve |image = Margaret Neve 110.jpg |alt = |caption = |birth_name = Margaret Ann Harvey |birth_date = {{birth date|1792|05|18|df=y}} |birth_place = [[St. Peter Port]], [[Guernsey]] |death_date = 4 April 1903
(aged {{age in years and days|1792|5|18|1903|4|4}}) |death_place = [[Guernsey]], [[United Kingdom]] |nationality = |known_for = *One of the first verified people that lived within 3 centuries (18th, 19th, and 20th). *The oldest verified human born before the [[19th century]] until [[Louisa Kirwan Thiers]] surpassed Neve's death age |spouse = John Neve (1823–1849, his death) }} '''Margaret Ann Neve''' (''née'' '''Harvey'''; 18 May 1792 – 4 April 1903) was the first recorded female [[supercentenarian]] and the second validated human to reach the age of 110 after [[Geert Adriaans Boomgaard]]. She lived at [[Saint Peter Port]] on the island of [[Guernsey]] in the [[English Channel]]. She was also the first proven individual whose life spanned three centuries (18th to the 20th centuries). ==Family== By Margaret's birth her family was already well-established on the island. Her father John Harvey was born in Cornwall in 1771 to John (1736-1778) and Margaret Ann Parker (d.1790). John Harvey was involved in merchant shipping and [[privateer]]ing, earning a great amount of wealth over the years. He married Elizabeth Harvey (''née'' Guille) when they were both 19. John died on 4 December 1820 at the age of 49, and Elizabeth lived with her remaining children in a house called "Chaumière" ("The Cottage"), which he had bought in 1808.{{cite web |url=http://www.priaulxlibrary.co.uk/priaulx-library-new-details2.asp?ItemID=95 |title=The Harvey Family |work=Priaulx Library |date=2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022135751/http://www.priaulxlibrary.co.uk/priaulx-library-new-details2.asp?ItemID=95 |archivedate=October 22, 2013}} Elizabeth died in 1871 at the age of 99. Together they had seven children: * Margaret (1792-1903) * John (1793-1865) - married Anne Sophia Grut (1802-1844) in 1826 and moved to Jersey, then England. They had a son named Thomas, who served in the militia and became a merchant. * Elizabeth (1796-) - never married. * Maria (1799) and Augusta (1801) had died as infants. * Thomas (1803) emigrated to the United States. * Augusta (1804) - married. * Louisa (1805-1821) ==Early life and marriage== Born Margaret Harvey on 18 May 1792, the eldest of seven children, most of her childhood was spent in [[Guernsey]]. Early in her life she survived a fall down the stairs, which left her [[concussion|concussed]] for three days. Neve, as she would become, could remember the turmoil that the [[French Revolution]] brought to Guernsey; at the time, her father was in command of the militia on the island. In 1807, at the age of 15, Neve set sail for [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]] with her father, but a storm caused the ship to land at [[Chesil Beach]].{{cite web |url=http://www.geog.cam.ac.uk/research/projects/chambersofcommerce/guernsey-1808-9.pdf |title=Guernsey (Channel Islands) chamber of commerce, members in 1808-9.}} She was educated in [[Bristol]], England, gaining an interest in literature and poetry. In 1815, she went to a "finishing school" in Brussels, becoming fluent in French and Italian and able to converse in German and Spanish. She would read the [[New Testament]] in Greek.{{rp|19}} With her headmistress, she visited the battlefield of [[Waterloo, Belgium|Waterloo]], shortly after [[Battle of Waterloo|the battle]], once the corpses had been buried. There, Margaret picked up souvenirs which she showed to Prussian Field Marshal [[Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher|Blücher]] in London.{{rp|19}} Neve met with [[Charles François Dumouriez]], a general of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]], who dubbed her "la spirituelle".{{cite news|title=Obituary|pages=10|publisher=[[The Times]]|date=1903-04-06}} Margaret married John Neve, born 1779, from [[Tenterden]], Kent,{{cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1903/04/19/101990032.pdf |title=The Late Mrs Neve |work=NY Times |date=19 April 1903}} in St Peter Port (Town) church on 18 January 1823. On their honeymoon, they visited the Waterloo battlefield, 8 years after the battle.{{cite news |title=AGED 110 YEARS |publisher=The Straits Times |date=7 May 1903 |page=6}} She lived in England for 25 years of marriage, but when her husband died in 1849, she returned to Guernsey.{{cite news|title=Her Hundred-and-eighth Birthday|pages=3|work=[[The Pall Mall Gazette]]|date=1900-05-18}} They had no children. == Later life and death == The census for 1871 shows Margaret A. Neve (78) and her sister Elizabeth Harvey (73) living at 'Chaumière', Rouge Huis, St Peter Port, Guernsey.RG10-5765-222-1 Neve traveled abroad to various countries with Elizabeth. Their last trip was in 1872, when Neve was 80, wherein they visited the Polish city of [[Krakow]] (then part of the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]]). On 18 May 1899, a reception was held at [[Rouge Huis]] to celebrate her 107th birthday and her entrance into her 108th year. The town council, [[jurat]]s, the officers of the staff, and about 250 of the leading residents attended.{{cite news |title=Unexampled Longevity. |pages=21 |work=[[The Pall Mall Gazette]]|date=1899-06-18}} Despite her age, Margaret was found making [[marmalade]] the next morning by a reporter from ''[[The Times]]''. She was reported as never being ill until the age of 105, when she had the flu, followed by bronchitis at 108. At the age of 110, she climbed a tree to pluck an apple, explaining that they were much tastier when eaten straight from the tree.{{cite book |first=Glen |last=Balfour-Pau |title=Bagpipes in Babylon: A Lifetime in the Arab World and Beyond |ISBN=9781845111519 |publisher=I.B.Tauris, 2006}}{{rp|18}} A newspaper report records that she enjoyed a glass and a half of old sherry at lunchtime, followed by a weak whiskey and water at supper. She was in the habit of always rising early and abstaining from eating and drinking between meal times.{{cite news |title=The Oldest Woman in the World |publisher=arence and Richmond Examiner |date=19 February 1901 |page=3}} Contrary to popular belief, she did not receive congratulations from [[Queen Victoria]] congratulating her for reaching her 110th birthday. However, the Harvey family (through Neve's niece Louisa) did exchange correspondence with the Royal Household, expressing gratitude for the signed photograph given to them on 4 May 1896 by the Queen. Neve died on 4 April 1903, a month before her 111th birthday. She reportedly repeated a [[Psalm]] in a loud voice the day before she died. Flags in Guernsey were lowered to half mast as a show of respect.{{rp|20}} She was one of the last few living people from the 18th century. ==See also== {{Portal|Channel Islands}} *[[List of British supercentenarians]] *[[List of the verified oldest people]] *[[Augusta Hejnek]] - Last surviving person from the 1700s *[[Salome Sellers]] - Last surviving person from the [[18th century]] *[http://www.grg.org/Gallery/Pre1850sgallery.html Gallery of supercentenarian's born before 1850] Gerontology Research Group (GRG), published 5 January 2018 ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{Use British English|date=October 2015}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Neve, Margaret Ann}} [[Category:1792 births]] [[Category:1903 deaths]] [[Category:Guernsey supercentenarians]] [[Category:Guernsey women]] [[Category:Female supercentenarians]] [[Category:Oldest people]]
