{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Use British English|date=June 2013}} [[File:The Seven Bishops Committed to the Tower in 1688 by John Smith.jpg|thumb|200px| ''The Seven Bishops Committed to the Tower in 1688'' by John Smith]] [[File:Trial of the Seven Bishops.jpg|thumb|200px| ''The Trial of the Seven Bishops'' by [[John Rogers Herbert]] ]] [[File:AcquittalSevenBishops.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The Seven Bishops greet the crowd after their acquittal (title and artist unknown)]] [[File:The Seven Bishops Committed to the Tower in 1688 by Pieter Schenck.jpg|thumb|200px| ''The Seven Bishops Committed to the Tower in 1688'' by [[Peter Schenk the Elder]] ]] The '''Seven Bishops''' of the [[Church of England]] were those imprisoned and tried for [[seditious libel]] related to their opposition to the second [[Declaration of Indulgence]], issued by [[James II of England|James II]] in 1688. In a major embarrassment to the Crown, they were found not guilty. ==Background== The Declaration granted broad religious freedom in England by suspending penal laws that enforced conformity to the Church of England, by allowing persons to worship in their homes or chapels as they saw fit, and by ending affirming religious oaths as a requirement for employment in government office. ==Sequence of events== The Declaration of Indulgence had originally been given out on 4 April 1687. The King republished it, with some new prefatory matter, on 25 April 1688. On 4 May the King and his council ordered the bishops that the declaration should be read in all the (Anglican) churches – those of London on 20 May and outside London on 27 May and the two following Sundays. This was the only way to make the document swiftly and generally known, which was James's straightforward object. The Anglican clergy felt it a challenge to themselves, for many of them were opposed to the toleration of Roman Catholics and Nonconformists, as were very many English people. Nine days passed with no objection; then, on 13 May, at [[Lambeth Palace]], Compton (Bishop of London), Sancroft (Archbishop of Canterbury), Turner (Bishop of Ely) and White (Bishop of Peterborough), resolved to defy James's order.Milne-Tyte, Robert, ''Bloody Jeffreys: the hanging judge'', André Deutsch, London, 1989, p. 189. They summoned seven others, of whom four actually came – Lake (Bishop of Chichester), Lloyd (St Asaph), Trelawny (Bristol) and Ken (Bath and Wells) – to a meeting of eight. Compton was under suspension following another dispute with the King. The others, known as the Seven Bishops, signed a petition requesting that they be excused; they claimed that the King did not have the legal right to make exemptions from statutes, the dispensing power having been declared illegal by Parliament.Carpenter, Edward, ''The Protestant Bishop: Being the Life of Henry Compton, 1632–1713, Bishop of London'', [[Longmans, Green and Co.]], 1956, p. 116. However, the King's power to dispense individuals from the provisions of a statute – that is to declare that the individual need not observe its provisions – had recently been reaffirmed in ''Godden v Hales''''State Trials'' Vol. IX pp1196-9 after James had dismissed judges he knew to be opposed to his exercise of it. The Lord Chief Justice, Sir [[Edward Herbert (judge)|Edward Herbert]], had ruled in ''Godden v Hales'' that : "It is an indispensable prerogative in the Kings of England to dispense with penal laws in particular cases, and upon particular necessary reasons...Of those reasons and those necessities the King himself is the sole judge."''State Trials'' On the night of Friday, 18 May, the Seven Bishops (apart from Sancroft) presented their petition to the King, who read it and was furious. He proclaimed it "a standard of rebellion" and dismissed them, saying that he expected to be obeyed and that "God hath given me this dispensing power and I will maintain it."Carpenter, p. 117. The petition was soon printed and distributed for sale on the streets of London; Compton may have been responsible for that. The seven were put on trial for seditious libel.Carpenter, p. 122. The council were not sure what to do, but summoned the Bishops to appear before them on Friday 8 June,Milne-Tyte, p. 189. which became known as Black Friday.[[Thomas Babington Macaulay|Macaulay, Thomas Babington]], ''The History Of England From the Accession of James II'', Vol. II, Chapter VIII, [[Donohue, Henneberry & Co.]], 1890, p. 332. [[s:The History Of England From the Accession of James II/Chapter VIII#II.332]]. The bishops could have given their own [[recognizance]]s for coming up for trial, and thereby avoided being imprisoned before their trial. Sancroft had urged this; even Compton agreed to it; but Sancroft changed his mind. The bishops seem to have been angling for a delay in the trial proceedings – by refusing to give recognizances, they would have the right to delay the trial until the beginning of Michaelmas term on 23 October. The king, however, wanted a speedy trial, and the only way to get it, apart from convincing the Bishops to give their own recognizances, was to imprison them in the [[Tower of London]] before their trial; within the Tower, however, they had complete freedom. Their imprisonment lasted only a week and had the effect, desired by the king, of speeding up the proceedings so that a trial could be held in June.Sowerby, Scott, ''Making Toleration: The Repealers and the Glorious Revolution'', Harvard University Press, 2013, pp. 178-81. But, in [[Hilaire Belloc]]'s deliberately ironic words, "Compton had had the satisfaction of seeing a vast popular gathering acclaiming these fathers in God on the way to the horrid dungeon of a Tyrant."Belloc, Hilaire, "James the Second", Faber & Gwyer, 1928, p. 216. The section from "The Declaration of Indulgence had originally" to this quotation is paraphrased from this book. [[George Jeffreys, 1st Baron Jeffreys|Lord Jeffreys]], the [[Lord Chancellor]], advised the King to drop the prosecution; on being overruled he asked caustically if the King was prepared to take advice from his Ministers or whether "the Virgin Mary is to do all".Milne-Tyte, p. 196. ==Trial== The trial took place at the Court of [[King's Bench]] on 29 June, with Sir [[Thomas Powys (judge)|Thomas Powys]] the Attorney General and [[Sir William Williams, 1st Baronet, of Gray's Inn|William Williams]] the Solicitor General prosecuting and Sir [[Robert Wright (judge)|Robert Wright]], the [[Lord Chief Justice]] as the presiding judge, sitting with [[John Powell (judge)|John Powell]], Richard Holloway and [[Richard Allibond]]. The bishops had a formidable team of defence counsel, headed by [[Francis Pemberton]], a former Lord Chief Justice, and including former Attorneys General [[Robert Sawyer (Attorney General)|Sir Robert Sawyer]] and [[Sir Creswell Levinz]], as well as [[John Somers, 1st Baron Somers|John Somers]], a future [[Lord Chancellor]].Kenyon, J.P., ''The Stuart Constitution'', 2nd Edition, Cambridge University Press, 1986, p. 391. The jury deliberated all night and the bishops were found not guilty on the morning of 30 June. There was great rejoicing; those opposed to the royal dispensing power had gained their victory. The verdict was a political disaster for the Government, largely due to its own ineptitude. Of the four judges only Allibond, a [[Roman Catholic]], showed any real desire for a conviction, while Powell and Holloway would clearly be happy with an acquittal. Powys, the Attorney General, through sheer incompetence, almost caused the case to collapse at the outset by failing to prove that the Petition had been presented at all; Williams, the Solicitor General, handled the case with greater skill, but his bitter personal feud with Lord Chief Justice Wright (who in the course of his summing-up to the jury accused him, without any relevance whatever to the trial, of taking bribes)Kenyon, p. 409. can scarcely have helped the prosecution. A modern historian remarked that the trial "had a strong element of the grotesque". ==Bishops== The Seven Bishops were: * [[William Sancroft]], [[Archbishop of Canterbury]] * [[Thomas Ken]], [[Bishop of Bath and Wells]] * [[John Lake (bishop)|John Lake]], [[Bishop of Chichester]] * [[William Lloyd (bishop of Worcester)|William Lloyd]], [[Bishop of St Asaph]] * [[Sir Jonathan Trelawny, 3rd Baronet|Jonathan Trelawny]], [[Bishop of Bristol]] * [[Francis Turner (bishop)|Francis Turner]], [[Bishop of Ely]] * [[Thomas White (bishop)|Thomas White]], [[Bishop of Peterborough]] Despite their petition and their trial, five of these bishops (all but Lloyd and Trelawny) remained loyal to James II after the [[Glorious Revolution]] and were among the nine bishops who became [[Nonjuring schism|non-juror]]s, refusing to swear an oath of allegiance to [[William III of England|William III]] and [[Mary II of England|Mary II]], and losing their bishoprics as a result. ==Rights of petition and religion== The bishops exercised the right to petition preserved in ''[[Magna Carta]]'' (1215) (clause 61). The following year Parliament cited James II's trial of the Seven Bishops as a grievance. It explicitly preserved the right of petition in the [[Bill of Rights 1689|Bill of Rights]] (1689).
"[T]he said Lords Spiritual and Temporal and Commons, ... do in the first place (as their ancestors in like case have usually done) for the vindicating and asserting their ancient rights and liberties declare ... That it is the right of the subjects to petition the king, and all commitments and prosecutions for such petitioning are illegal; ..."
These rights of petition for redress of grievances and of religion and conscience were preserved in the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. ==See also== *[[Bill of Rights 1689]] ==References== {{reflist|25em}} {{Commons category|Seven Bishops}} ==External links== * [http://yarchive.net/macaulay/history/chapter_VIII.html Chapter VIII] of Macaulay's [[The History of England from the Accession of James the Second|''History of England'']] – the last third describes the circumstances of the Petition and Trial of the Seven Bishops * [http://www.jacobite.ca/documents/16880518.htm Petition of the Seven Bishops] * [http://anglicanhistory.org/nonjurors/ Documents by and about the Nonjurors] at [[Project Canterbury]] * William Gibson, ''James II and the Trial of the Seven Bishops'' (Palgrave Macmillan, 2009). [https://www.amazon.com/James-II-Trial-Seven-Bishops/dp/0230204007#reader_0230204007 preview] * {{cite book | author = Herbert Mortimer Luckock | title = The bishops in the tower | year = 1896 | publisher = London}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=hQEMAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Bishops+in+the+Tower&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ymM9T6TGM4-y0QGu38HVBw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Bishops%20in%20the%20Tower&f=false ebook] * {{cite book | author = [[Agnes Strickland]] | title = The Lives of the Seven Bishops Committed to the Tower in 1688 | year = 1866 }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=jmgNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA1&dq=lives+of+the+seven+bishops&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6GQ9T7j7ONKs0AHh6ZmxBw&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=lives%20of%20the%20seven%20bishops&f=false ebook] * {{cite book | title = The life of Archbishop Sancroft | year = 1840 |author = [[George D'Oyly]] | publisher = John W. Parker, London}} [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=RjtKAAAAMAAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PA1&dq=W.+K.+Stewart,+%22The+Trial+of+the+Seven+Bishops%22&ots=2D8EX5otae&sig=6iPFLAZsm7rqpTLNCOpbZ_WhZZE#v=onepage&q&f=false ebook] {{DEFAULTSORT:Seven Bishops}} [[Category:Cultural lists|7 Seven Bishops]] [[Category:History of the Church of England]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]] [[Category:Stuart England]] [[Category:17th-century Anglican bishops]]

[[File:70Apostles.jpg|thumb|[[Icon]] of the Seventy Apostles.{{when|date=October 2015}}]] The '''seventy disciples''' or '''seventy-two disciples''' (known in the [[Eastern Christianity|Eastern Christian]] traditions as the '''Seventy[-two] Apostles''') were early emissaries of [[Jesus]] mentioned in the [[Gospel of Luke]].{{bibleref2|Luke|10:1–24}} According to Luke, the only [[gospel]] in which they appear, Jesus appointed them and sent them out in pairs on a specific mission which is detailed in the text. In [[Western Christianity]], they are usually referred to as [[Disciple (Christianity)|disciples]],[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/05029a.htm Catholic Encyclopedia: Disciple]: "The disciples, in this disciples, in this context, are not the crowds of believers who flocked around Christ, but a smaller body of His followers. They are commonly identified with the seventy-two (seventy, according to the received Greek text, although several Greek manuscripts mention seventy-two, as does the Vulgate) referred to ({{bibleref2|Luke|10:1}}) as having been chosen by Jesus. The names of these disciples are given in several lists (Chronicon Paschale, and Pseudo-Dorotheus in Migne, P.G., XCII, 521–524; 543–545; 1061–1065); but these lists are unfortunately worthless." whereas in Eastern Christianity they are usually referred to as [[Apostle (Christian)|Apostles]].{{cite web|url=http://ocafs.oca.org/FeastSaintsLife.asp?FSID=100017|title=Synaxis of the Seventy Apostles|work=oca.org}} Using the original [[Greek language|Greek words]], both titles are descriptive, as an ''apostle'' is one sent on a [[Mission (Christian)|mission]] (the Greek uses the verb form: ''apesteilen'') whereas a ''disciple'' is a student, but the two traditions differ on the scope of the words ''apostle'' and ''disciple''. Although apostles and disciples exist in many extant churches and denominations, the [[Latter Day Saint movement]] is the only current one to use [[Seventy (Latter Day Saints)|Seventy]] as a title for a priesthood office.{{sourcetext|source=The Doctrine and Covenants|book=Section 107|verse=25|showsource=x}} == Text == The passage from [[Luke 10]] reads (in [[Young's Literal Translation]]):{{quote| And after these things, the Lord did appoint also other seventy, and sent them by twos before his face, to every city and place whither he himself was about to come, then said he unto them, `The harvest indeed [is] abundant, but the workmen few; beseech ye then the Lord of the harvest, that He may put forth workmen to His harvest. `Go away; lo, I send you forth as lambs in the midst of wolves; carry no bag, no scrip, nor sandals; and salute no one on the way; and into whatever house ye do enter, first say, Peace to this house; and if indeed there may be there the son of peace, rest on it shall your peace; and if not so, upon you it shall turn back. `And in that house remain, eating and drinking the things they have, for worthy [is] the workman of his hire; go not from house to house, and into whatever city ye enter, and they may receive you, eat the things set before you, and heal the ailing in it, and say to them, The reign of God hath come nigh to you. `And into whatever city ye do enter, and they may not receive you, having gone forth to its broad places, say, And the dust that hath cleaved to us, from your city, we do wipe off against you, but this know ye, that the reign of God hath come nigh to you; and I say to you, that for Sodom in that day it shall be more tolerable than for that city. `Wo to thee, Chorazin; wo to thee, Bethsaida; for if in Tyre and Sidon had been done the mighty works that were done in you, long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes, they had reformed; but for Tyre and Sidon it shall be more tolerable in the judgment than for you. `And thou, Capernaum, which unto the heaven wast exalted, unto hades thou shalt be brought down. `He who is hearing you, doth hear me; and he who is putting you away, doth put me away; and he who is putting me away, doth put away Him who sent me.' And the seventy turned back with joy, saying, `Sir, and the demons are being subjected to us in thy name;' and he said to them, `I was beholding the Adversary, as lightning from the heaven having fallen; lo, I give to you the authority to tread upon serpents and scorpions, and on all the power of the enemy, and nothing by any means shall hurt you; but, in this rejoice not, that the spirits are subjected to you, but rejoice rather that your names were written in the heavens.'{{bibleref2|Luke|10:1–20|YLT}}}} == Analysis == This is the only mention of the group in the [[Bible]]. The number is ''seventy'' in some manuscripts of the [[Alexandrian text-type|Alexandrian]] (such as [[Codex Sinaiticus]]) and [[Caesarean text-type|Caesarean]] text traditions but ''seventy-two'' in most other Alexandrian and [[Western text-type|Western]] texts. It may derive from the [[Sons of Noah|seventy nations of Genesis 10]] or the many other occurrences of the number seventy in the Bible, or the seventy-two translators of the [[Septuagint]] from the [[Letter of Aristeas]].[[Bruce Metzger]]'s ''Textual Commentary on the Greek NT'' In translating the ''[[Vulgate]]'', [[Jerome]] selected the reading of seventy-two. The ''Gospel of Luke'' is not alone among the [[synoptic gospels]] in containing multiple episodes in which Jesus sends out his followers on missions. The first occasion ({{bibleref2|Luke|9:1–6}}) is closely based on the "limited commission" mission in ''[[Gospel of Mark|Mark]]'' {{bibleref2|Mark|6:6–13}}, which however recounts the sending out of the [[twelve apostles]], rather than seventy, though with similar details. The parallels (also [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] {{bibleref2|Matthew|9:35}}, {{bibleref2|Matthew|10:1}}, {{bibleref2|Matthew|10:5–42}}) suggest a common origin in the hypothesized [[Q document]]. Luke also mentions the [[Great Commission]] to "all nations" ({{bibleref2|Luke|24:44–49}}) but in less detail than Matthew's account and {{bibleverse|Mark|16:19–20}} mentions the [[Dispersion of the Apostles]]. What has been said to the seventy (two) in {{bibleref2|Luke|10:4}} is referred in passing to the Twelve in {{bibleref2|Luke|22:35}}: :He said to them, "When I sent you forth without a money bag or a sack or sandals, were you in need of anything?" "No, nothing," they replied. == Feast days == [[File:Erastus, Olympus, Rhodion, Sosipater, Quartus and Tertius (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumbnail|Erastus, Olympus, Rhodion, Sosipater, Quartus and Tertius]] [[File:Stachys, Amplias, Urban (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumbnail|Stachys, Amplias, Urban]] [[File:Patrobulus, Hermas, Linus, Caius, Philologus of 70 disciples (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumbnail|Patrobulus, Hermas, Linus, Caius, Philologus]] [[File:Sosthenes, Apollo, Cephas, Tychicus, Epaphroditus, Cæsar and Onesiphorus of 70 disciples (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumbnail|Sosthenes, Apollo, Cephas, Tychicus, Epaphroditus, Cæsar and Onesiphorus]] The [[feast day]] commemorating the seventy is known as the "[[Synaxis]] of the Seventy Apostles" in Eastern Orthodoxy, and is celebrated on [[January 4 (Eastern Orthodox liturgics)|January 4]]. Each of the seventy apostles also has individual commemorations scattered throughout the [[liturgical year]] (see [[Eastern Orthodox Church calendar]]). == The record by Pseudo-Hippolytus == [[Hippolytus of Rome]] was a disciple of [[Irenaeus]], a disciple of [[Polycarp]], a disciple of [[Apostle John]]. Hippolytus's works were considered lost prior to their discovery at a monastery on [[Mount Athos]] in 1854.Ante-Nicean Fathers, ed. Alexander Roberts, James Donaldson and A. Cleaveland Coxe, vol. 5 (Peabody MA: Hendrickson Publishers, 1999), 3 While his major work ''The Refutation of All Heresies'' was readily accepted (once the false attribution to Origen was resolved), his two small works, ''On the Twelve Apostles of Christ'' and ''On the Seventy Apostles of Christ'', are still regarded as dubious, put in the appendix of his works in the voluminous collection of the writings of early church fathers.Ante-Nicean Fathers, ed. Alexander Roberts, James Donaldson and A. Cleaveland Coxe, vol. 5 (Peabody MA: Hendrickson Publishers, 1999), 254–56 Here is the complete text of Pseudo-Hippolytus's ''On the Seventy Apostles of Christ'':
# [[James the Just|James the Lord's brother]], bishop of Jerusalem. # [[Cleopas]], bishop of Jerusalem. # [[Saint Matthias|Matthias]], who supplied the vacant place in the number of the twelve apostles. # [[Thaddeus of Edessa|Thaddeus]], who conveyed the epistle to Augarus ([[Abgar V]]). # [[Ananias of Damascus|Ananias]], who baptized Paul, and was bishop of Damascus. # [[St Stephen|Stephen]], the first martyr. # [[Philip the Evangelist|Philip]], who baptized the eunuch. # [[Prochorus (deacon)|Prochorus]], bishop of Nicomedia, who also was the first that departed, 11 believing together with his daughters. # [[Nicanor the Deacon|Nicanor]] died when Stephen was martyred. # [[Timon the Deacon|Timon]], bishop of Bostra. # [[Parmenas]], bishop of Soli. # [[Nicolas the Deacon|Nicolaus]], bishop of Samaria. # [[Barnabas]], bishop of Milan. # [[Mark the Evangelist]], bishop of Alexandria. # [[Luke the Evangelist]]. These two belonged to the seventy disciples who were scattered by the offence of the word which Christ spoke, “Except a man eat my flesh, and drink my blood, he is not worthy of me.” But the one being induced to return to the Lord by Peter’s instrumentality, and the other by Paul’s, they were honored to preach that Gospel on account of which they also suffered martyrdom, the one being burned, and the other being crucified on an olive tree.

  27. and 43. [[Olympas|Olympus]] and [[Herodion of Patras|Rhodion]] were martyred in Rome.
  1. [[Lucius of Cyrene|Lucius]], bishop of Laodicea in Syria.
  2. [[Jason of Thessalonica|Jason]], bishop of Tarsus.
  3. [[Sosipater]], bishop of Iconium
  4. [[Tertius of Iconium|Tertius]], bishop of Iconium.

  11. [[Epaphroditus]], bishop of Andriace.
  12. [[Caesar of Dyrrhachium|Cæsar]], bishop of Dyrrachium.
  13. [[Mark of Apollonias|Mark]], cousin to Barnabas, bishop of Apollonia.
  14. [[Justus of Eleutheropolis|Justus]], bishop of Eleutheropolis.
  15. [[Artemas of Lystra|Artemas]], bishop of Lystra.
  16. [[Clement of Sardice|Clement]], bishop of Sardinia.
  17. [[Onesiphorus]], bishop of Corone.
  18. [[Tychicus of Chalcedon|Tychicus]], bishop of Chalcedon.

  20. [[Evodius|Evodus]], bishop of Antioch.

== The first list and other lists == Many of the names included among the seventy are recognizable for their other achievements. The names included in various lists differ slightly. In the lists, [[Luke the Evangelist|Luke]] is also one of these seventy himself. The following list gives a widely accepted [[wikt:canon|canon]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} Their names are listed below: # James "the Lord's brother" ([[James the Just]]), author of the [[Epistle of James]], and first [[Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem#Bishops of Jerusalem|Bishop of Jerusalem]]. {{bibleref2|Matthew|13:55}}; {{bibleref2|Mark|6:3}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|12:17}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|15:13}}; [[Epistle of James]]. # Agabus. Other names commonly included are:{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} * Another Stephen * [[Rodion]] * [[Cephas of Iconium|Cephas]], Bishop of Iconium * [[Caesar of Dyrrhachium|Caesar]], Bishop of [[Dyrrhachium]] * Another [[Mark of Apollonias|Mark]], Bishop of [[Apollonias]] * Another [[Tychicus of Chalcedon|Tychicus]], [[Bishop of Chalcedon]] in Bithynia These are usually included at the expense of the aforementioned Timothy, Titus, Archippus, Crescens, Olympas, Epaphroditus, Quadratus, Aquila, Fortunatus, and/or Achaicus. [[Bishop]] Solomon of [[Basra]] of the [[Church of the East]] in the 13th century offers the following list: :''The names of the seventy''. # [[James the Just|James]], the son of Joseph; # [[Symeon of Jerusalem|Simon the son of Cleopas]]; # [[Cleopas]], his father; # [[Joses]]; # [[Simon (brother of Jesus)|Simon]]; # [[Jude, brother of Jesus|Judah]]; # Barnabas; # Manaeus (?); # [[Ananias of Damascus|Ananias]], who baptised Paul; # [[Aramaic of Jesus#Cephas|Cephas]], who preached at Antioch; # [[Joseph of Arimathea|Joseph the senator]]; # Nicodemus the archon; # Nathaniel the chief scribe; # [[Joseph Barsabbas|Justus, that is Joseph, who is called Barshabbâ]]; # Silas; # Judah; # John, surnamed Mark (John Mark); # [[Mnason]], who received Paul; # Manaël, the foster-brother of Herod; # [[Simeon Niger|Simon]] called Niger; # [[Jason of Thessalonica|Jason]], who is (mentioned) in the Acts (of the apostles); # [[Saints Rufus|Rufus]]; # Alexander; # [[Simon of Cyrene|Simon the Cyrenian, their father]]; # [[Lucius of Cyrene|Lucius the Cyrenian]]; # Another [[Judas Barsabbas|Judah]], who is mentioned in the Acts (of the apostles); # Judah, who is called Simon; # Eurion (Orion) the splay-footed; # Thôrus (?); # Thorîsus (?); # Zabdon; # Zakron.'' A more concise and acknowledged list{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} is below: # Archaicus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|16:17}} # Agabus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|11:28}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|21:10}} # Amplias, appointed by [[St. Andrew]] as bishop of [[Lod|Lydda]] of Odyssopolis (Diospolis) in [[Judea]]. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:8}}. # [[Ananias of Damascus|Ananias]], who baptized St. Paul. He was the bishop of Damascus. He became a martyr by being stoned in Eleutheropolis. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|9:10–17}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|22:12}} # Andronicus, bishop of Pannonia. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:7}} # Apelles, bishop of Heraclea (in Trachis). Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:10}} # Apollos. He was a bishop of several places over time: Crete (though this is questioned), Corinth, [[Smyrna]], and Caesarea. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|18:24}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|19:1}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|1:12}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|3:4–22}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|4:6}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|16:12}}, {{bibleref2|Titus|3:13}} # Aquila. He was martyred. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|18:2}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|18}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|26}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:3}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|16:19}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:19}} # Archippus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:17}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|2}} # Aristarchus, bishop of Apamea in Syria. He was martyred under [[Nero]]. “Aristarchus, whom [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] mentions several times, calling him a ‘fellow laborer,’ became bishop of Apamea in Syria.” [[Orthodox Study Bible]] Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|19:29}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|27:2}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:10}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|24}} # Aristobulus, bishop of Britain. “… the brother of the apostle Barnabas, preached the gospel in [[Great Britain]] and died peacefully there.” Orthodox Study Bible Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # Artemas, bishop of Lystra in Lycia. Reference to in Titus 3:12 # [[Aristarchus of Thessalonica|Aristarchus]], bishop of Hyracania in [[Asia]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # [[Barnabas]]. “A Jew of the Tribe of Levi, was born in [[Cyprus]] of wealthy parents. He is said to have studied under Gamaliel with Saul of [[Tarsus, Mersin|Tarsus]], who was to become Paul the apostle. Originally named Joseph, he was called Barnabas (Son of Consolation) by the apostles because he had a rare gift of comforting people’s hearts. He sought out Paul when everyone else was afraid of him, bringing him to the apostles. It was Barnabas whom the apostles first sent to [[Antioch]] with Paul. Their long association was broken only when Barnabas was determined to take his cousin Mark, whom Paul did not trust just then, on a missionary journey. The three were later reconciled. Many ancient accounts say Barnabas was the first to preach in [[Rome]] and in [[Milan]], but he was martyred in Cyprus, then buried by [[Mark the Evangelist|Mark]] at the western gate of the city of Salamis.” Orthodox Study Bible Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|4:36}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|9:27}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|11–15}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|9:6}}; {{bibleref2|Galatians|2:1, 9, 13}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:10}} # Caesar, bishop of Dyrrhachium (in the [[Peloponnese]] of [[Greece]]) # Carpus, bishop of Berroia (Verria, in Macedonia. Reference to in 2 Timothy 4:13 # Clement, bishop in Sardis. Reference to in Philippians 4:3 # Cephas, bishop of Iconium, Pamphyllia. # Cleopas, was with the Lord on the road to [[Emmaus]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Luke|24:18}}; {{bibleref2|John|19:25}} # Crescens, later bishop of [[Galatia]]. He was martyred under the Emperor Trajan. Reference to in 2 Timothy 4:10 # Crispus, bishop of [[Aegina]], Greece. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|18:8}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|1:14}} # Epaphras. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Colossians|1:7}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:12}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|23}} # Epaphroditus, bishop of the Thracian city of Adriaca. Reference to in Philippians 2:25; 4:18 # Epaenetus, bishop of Carthage. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:5}} # Erastus. He served as a deacon and steward to the Church of Jerusalem. Later he served in Palestine. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|19:22}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:23}}; 2 Timothy 4:20 # Euodias(Evodius), first bishop of Antioch after [[St.Peter]]. He wrote several compositions. At the age of sixty-six, under the Emperor Nero, he was martyred. Reference to in Philippians 4:2 # Fortunatus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|16:17}} # Gaius, bishop of Ephesus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|19:29}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:23}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|1:14}}; {{bibleref2|3 John|1}} # Hermas, bishop in Philipopoulis. He wrote ''The Shepherd of Hermas.'' He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # Hermes, bishop of Dalmatia. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # Herodion, a relative of the Apostle Paul, bishop of Neoparthia. He was beheaded in [[Rome]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:11}} # [[James the Just|James, brother of the Lord]] (also called "the Less" or "the Just"). James was the Patriarch of Jerusalem. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Matthew|13:55}}; {{bibleref2|Mark|6:3}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|12:17}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|15:13}}; [[Epistle of James]] # Jason, bishop of [[Tarsus, Mersin|Tarsus]]. Traveling with Sosipater to Corfu, the two were able, after an attempt made at their lives by the king of Corfu, to convert his majesty. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|17:5–9}} # Justus, brother to the Lord and bishop of Eleutheropolis. He was the half-brother of Christ (as was Sts. James, Jude, and Simon) through Joseph's previous marriage to Salome. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|1:23}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|18:7}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:11}} # Linus, bishop of Rome. Reference to in 2 Timothy 4:21 # Lucius, bishop of [[Laodicea on the Lycus|Laodicea]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|13:1}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:21}} # [[Luke the Evangelist]]. He is the author of the Gospel of Luke, and the founder of [[Iconography]] (Orthodox Icon-writing). Reference to in {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:14}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:11}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|24}} # [[Mark the Evangelist]] (called John). He wrote the Gospel of Mark. He also founded the Church of [[Alexandria]], serving as its first bishop. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|12:12}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|25}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|15:37–39}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:10}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:11}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|24}}; {{bibleref2|1 Peter|5:13}} # Mark # Narcissus, ordained by the Apostle Philip as bishop of [[Athens]], Greece. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:11}} # [[Nicanor the Deacon|Nicanor]], one of the original seven [[deacon]]s. He was martyred on the same day as the Promartyr Stephen. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # Olympas, beheaded with St. [[Saint Peter|Peter]] under Nero. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:15}} # Onesimus. Onesimus preached the Gospel in many cities. He was made bishop of Ephesus, and later bishop of [[Byzantium]] ([[Constantinople]]). He was martyred under the Emperor Trajan. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:9}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|10}} # Onesiphorus, bishop of Colophon (Asia Minor), and later of Corinth. He died a martyr in Parium. Reference to in 2 Timothy 1:16; 4:19 # Parmenas, one of the original seven deacons. He preached throughout Asia Minor, and later settled in Macedonia. He was a bishop of Soli. He died a martyr in Macedonia. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # Patrobus, bishop of Neapolis ([[Naples]]). Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # [[Philemon (New Testament person)|Philemon]]. He, with his wife Apphia, and the apostle Archippus, were martyred by pagans during a pagan feast. Reference to in Philemon 1 # Philip the Deacon (one of the original seven). He was born in Palestine, and later preached throughout its adjoining lands. In Acts, he converts a eunuch (an official) of Candace, queen of Ethiopia, to Christ. He was later made bishop by the apostles at Jerusalem, who also sent him to Asia Minor. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|8}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|21:8}} # Philologus, ordained bishop of Sinope (near the [[Black sea]]) by the Apostle [[Saint Andrew|Andrew]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:15}} # Phlegon, bishop of [[Marathon]], in Thrace. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # Prochorus, one of the original seven deacons. He was made bishop of Nicomedia by [[St. Peter]]. He was later banished with the Apostle John ([[John the Theologian]]) to the Island of [[Patmos]]. In Antioch, he died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # Pudens (Pastorum). He was an esteemed member of the [[Roman Senate]], then received Sts. Peter and Paul into his home, and was converted to [[Christ]] by them. He was martyred under Nero. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # Quadratus, bishop of Athens. He was author of the ''Apologia''. He was stoned, but survived. Soon-after, he died of starvation in prison. # Quartus, bishop of [[Beirut]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:23}} # Rufus, bishop of [[Thebes, Greece|Thebes]], Greece. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Mark|15:21}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:13}} # Silas (Silvanus), bishop of Corinth. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|15:22–40}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|16:19–40}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|17:4–15}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|18:5}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|1:19}}; {{bibleref2|1 Thessalonians|1:1}}; {{bibleref2|2 Thessalonians|1:1}}; {{bibleref2|1 Peter|5:12}} # [[Simeon of Jerusalem|Simeon]], son of Cleopas. “Simeon, son of Cleopas (who was the brother of [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]], the betrothed of the [[Virgin Mary]]), succeeded James as [[Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem|bishop of Jerusalem]].” Orthodox Study Bible. He was martyred through torture and crucifixion, at the age of one-hundred. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Matthew|13:55}}; {{bibleref2|Mark|6:3}} # Sosipater, ordained bishop of Iconium by the Apostle [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]], his relative. With St. Jason, he converted the king of [[Corfu]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:21}} # Sosthenes. “… became bishop of Caesarea.” Orthodox Study Bible Reference to in {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|1:1}} # Stachys, ordained by [[St. Andrew]] to be bishop of Byzantium. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:9}} # [[Saint Stephen|Stephen the Promartyr]] and Archdeacon (one of the original seven deacons). Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5–7:60}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|8:2}} ({{bibleref2|Acts|6:5–8:2}}); {{bibleref2|Acts|11:19}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|22:20}} # Tertius, bishop of Iconium (after Sosipater). He wrote down St. Paul's letter to the Romans. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:22}} # Thaddaeus. He was baptized by [[John the Baptist]] (John the Forerunner). He later preached, and founded a Church in Beirut. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Matthew|10:3}}; {{bibleref2|Mark|3:18}} # Timon, one of the original seven deacons, and later bishop of Bostra (in [[Arabia]]). He was thrown into a furnace, but emerged unharmed. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # [[Saint Timothy|Timothy]]. He accompanied [[St. Paul]] often, and both 1 and 2 Timothy are addressed to him. He was ordained bishop of Ephesus by St. Paul. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|16:1}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|17:14}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|15}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|18:5}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|19:22}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:21}}; 1 and 2 Timothy # [[Saint Titus|Titus]]. “Among the more prominent of the seventy was the apostle Titus, whom [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] called his brother and his son. Born in Crete, Titus was educated in [[Greek philosophy]], but after reading the prophet [[Isaiah]] he began to doubt the value of all he had been taught. Hearing the news of the coming of [[Jesus Christ]], he joined some others from Crete who were going to [[Jerusalem]] to see for themselves. After hearing Jesus speak and seeing His works, the young Titus joined those who followed Him. Baptized by the apostle Paul, he worked with and served the great apostle of the [[gentiles]], traveling with him until Paul sent him to Crete, making him bishop of that city. It is said that Titus was in Rome at the time of the beheading of St. Paul and that he buried the body of his spiritual father before returning home. Back in Crete, he converted and baptized many people, governing the Church on that island until he entered into rest at the age of ninety-four.” Orthodox Study Bible Reference to in {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|2:13}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|7:6–14}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|8:6–23}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|12:18}}; {{bibleref2|Galatians|2:1–3}}; Epistle to Titus # Trophimus, disciple of [[St. Paul]], and martyred under Nero. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|21:29}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:20}} # Tychicus. “… succeeded him (Sosthenes, as bishop) in that city (of Caesarea).” Orthodox Study Bible. He delivered St. Paul's letter to the Ephesians and Colossians. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Ephesians|6:21}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:7}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:12}}; {{bibleref2|Titus|3:12}} # Urbanus, ordained by the [[Apostle Andrew]] as bishop of [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]]. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:9}} # Zenas (called 'the lawyer'), bishop of Diospolis ([[Lod|Lydda]]), in [[Timeline of the name "Palestine"|Palestine]]. Reference to in Titus 3:13 Additional Names: # Alphaeus, father of the apostles James and Matthew. # Apphia, wife of the Apostle Philemon. The Church had gathered in her home for liturgy, while pagans who had been celebrating a pagan feast broke in and raided her home. They took Apphia, Philemon, and Archippus to be killed. She suffered martyrdom, and is commemorated by the Church on February 19. # Junia, accompanied Andronicus in preaching all over Pannonia. She was a relative to the Apostle Paul, and a martyr. # Silvan, bishop of [[Thessaloniki]], Greece. Reference to in {{bibleref2|1 Peter|5:12}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|1:19}} # [[Zacchaeus]], appointed by St. Peter to be bishop of Caesarea, referred to in {{bibleref2|Luke|19:1–10}} == Manuscripts of the New Testament with lists == * [[Minuscule 82]] * [[Minuscule 93]] * [[Minuscule 177]] * [[Minuscule 459]] * [[Minuscule 613]] * [[Minuscule 617]] * [[Minuscule 699]] == See also == {{portal|Christianity}} * [[Life of Jesus in the New Testament]] * [[Dispersion of the Apostles]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://orthodoxwiki.org/Seventy_Apostles Orthodoxwiki.org, ''Seventy Apostles''']. {{About|the women's rights advocates|other uses|The Famous Five (disambiguation){{!}}The Famous Five}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Main|Edwards v. Canada (Attorney General)}} [[File:Women are Persons-two.jpg|thumb|right|[[Louise McKinney]] and [[Henrietta Muir Edwards]], Famous Five statue, [[Parliament Hill]], [[Ottawa]]]] '''The Famous Five''', or '''The Valiant Five''',<ref>{{cite book|last=Kome|first=Penney|title=Women of Influence: Canadian Women and Politics|year=1985|publisher=Doubleday Canada|location=Toronto|isbn=978-0-385-23140-4|pages=31–32|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=CBF8UvjlN8KiyAGu3IHwDg&id=hBQqAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22valiant+five%22+emily+murphy&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22valiant+five%22|edition=1st}}</ref> ({{Lang-fr|Célèbres cinq}}) were five Alberta women who asked the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] to answer the question, "Does the word 'Persons' in Section 24 of the [[Constitution Act, 1867|British North America Act, 1867]], include female persons?" in the case ''[[Edwards v Canada (AG)|Edwards v Canada]].''<ref name=Brennan>{{cite book | first=Brian| last=Brennan| title=Alberta Originals: Stories of Albertans Who Made a Difference| year=2001| publisher= Fifth House| page= 14| isbn= 1-894004-76-0}}</ref> The five women, [[Emily Murphy]], [[Irene Parlby|Irene Marryat Parlby]], [[Nellie McClung|Nellie Mooney McClung]], [[Louise McKinney|Louise Crummy McKinney]] and [[Henrietta Muir Edwards]], created a petition to ask this question. They fought to have women legally considered persons so that women could be appointed to the Senate. The petition was filed on August 27, 1927,<ref name="Alberta1999">{{cite book| title=Alberta History| volume=47–49| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jL06AQAAIAAJ&q=famous+five+persons+case+august+27&dq=famous+five+persons+case+august+27| accessdate=May 10, 2013| year=1999| publisher=Historical Society of Alberta}}</ref> and on April 24, 1928, Canada's Supreme Court summarized its unanimous decision that women are not such "persons".<ref name = Brennan/>
The last line of the judgement reads, "Understood to mean 'Are women eligible for appointment to the [[Senate of Canada]],' the question is answered in the negative." This judgement was overturned by the British [[Judicial Committee of the Privy Council]] on October 18, 1929. This case came to be known as the "[[Persons Case]]". Although Canadian women (those who were British/Canadian citizens) had the vote in many provinces and in federal elections by 1929, the case was part of a continent-wide drive for political equality, coming seven years after discrimination against women's voting rights was prohibited in the United States through the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]], and thus had important ramifications.
Some saw this as "radical change"; others saw it as a restoration of the original framing of the English constitutional documents, including the [[1689 Bill of Rights]], which uses only the term "person", not the term "man" (or "woman" for that matter).
Some others have interpreted the Privy Council rule as causing a change in the Canadian judicial approach to the [[Constitution of Canada|Canadian constitution]], an approach that has come to be known as the "[[living tree doctrine]]".
[[Image:The Valiant Five Statue.jpg|thumb|220px|Statue in [[downtown Calgary]] of the Famous Five. An identical statue exists on [[Parliament Hill]], [[Ottawa]]]] [[File:The Famous Five.JPG|thumb|Part of the Famous Five monument on [[Olympic Plaza (Calgary)|Olympic Plaza]] in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], Canada]]
==The Five== The famous five women were:
* [[Emily Murphy]] (1868–1933), the [[British Empire]]'s first female judge; * [[Irene Parlby|Irene Marryat Parlby]] (1868–1965), farm women's leader, political activist and first female [[Cabinet minister]] in Alberta, still serving in that capacity at the time of the court case; * [[Nellie McClung|Nellie Mooney McClung]] (1873–1951), a [[suffragist]] and author, member of the Alberta Legislature 1921–1926; * [[Louise McKinney|Louise Crummy McKinney]] (1868–1931), the first woman elected to the [[Legislative Assembly of Alberta]], or any legislature in Canada or the rest of the British Empire, but no longer MLA at the time of the court case; * [[Henrietta Muir Edwards]] (1849–1931), an advocate for working women, author and a founding member of the [[Victorian Order of Nurses]].
===Emily Murphy=== {{Main|Emily Murphy}} Emily Murphy stood out in the famous five, bringing them to a victory in 1929. Emily was appointed to the office of Magistrate of the Edmonton Juvenile Court in 1916 and later became the magistrate of the newly created Women's Court. At the time, no woman had held such a position and many men objected.<ref name=MacEwan>{{cite book |first=Grant| last=MacEwan| title=...and Mighty Women too: Stories of Notable Western Canadian Women| year=1975| publisher= Western Producer Prairie Books| isbn=978-0919306653}}</ref>
During her career as a writer, Murphy used the pen name "Janey Canuck". In 1922, she wrote ''The Black Candle'' which detailed her beliefs on race and drug use in Canada and strongly influenced the drug policy of the day. Murphy came from a privileged background in which white women were protected from many topics.<ref name="Millar">{{cite book |first=Nancy |last=Millar |title=The Famous Five: Five Canadian Women and Their Fight to Become Persons |year=1999 |publisher=Western Heritage Centre| isbn=978-0920109168}}</ref>
===Irene Parlby=== {{Main|Irene Parlby}} In 1916, Irene Parlby was elected as the first president of the United Farm Women of Alberta and in 1921, was elected to the Alberta legislature and received a cabinet post in the United Farmers of Alberta government, becoming the second woman in the British Empire to hold ministerial rank. She served as cabinet minister until the downfall of the government in 1935. Parlby worked with the Red Cross during [[World War I]] and later served on the Board of Governors of the [[University of Alberta]].<ref name=MacEwan/>
===Nellie McClung=== {{Main|Nellie McClung}} Nellie McClung's jobs in her lifetime included teacher, author, public speaker, temperance activist, internationally known women's rights activist, and politician {Warne, Literature as Pulpit]. In 1918, she was a member of the Dominion War Council and the only woman representative at the League of Nations. She represented Canada at the Ecumenical Council of the Methodist church in 1921 and was the first woman on the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] Board of the Governors.<ref name=MacEwan/> In 1921, McClung was elected to the Alberta legislature as an MLA in Edmonton for the Liberal Party.<ref name=Millar/> She served one term, not being re-elected in 1926. She was a member of the Political Equality League of Manitoba, and she played the leading role in the Mock Parliament held on January 29, 1914, at the Walker Theatre in Winnipeg, which humorously discussed Votes for Men.<ref name=MacEwan/>
===Louise McKinney=== {{Main|Louise McKinney}} Louise McKinney became one of the first two women elected to a legislature in the British Empire, and the first to take her seat. She was a founder of the [[Woman's Christian Temperance Union]] in Alberta and the West – she served as the organization's vice-president for more than 22 years beginning in 1906 – and regularly attended World Meetings of the WCTU. She signed the appeal to the Privy Council in 1929. In 1931, she became president of the Canadian Union, Woman's Christian Temperance Union. McKinney was also named to be Commissioner for the first General Council of the [[United Church of Canada]], and was the only woman to sign the Basis of Union.<ref name=MacEwan/>
===Henrietta Muir Edwards=== {{Main|Henrietta Muir Edwards}} Henrietta Muir Edwards, author and researcher on women's topics, held an influence within the National Council of Women<ref name = Brennan/> and held chairmanship of the Committee in Law in the National Council of Women for more than 35 years. She was also a Red Cross leader during the war years. Edwards was the secretary of the National Subcommittee which focused on thrift and economy in Canadian homes.<ref name=MacEwan/>
==Legacy==
===Honorary senators=== None of the five became [[Senate of Canada#Senators|senators]]; the first female senator was Quebecer [[Cairine Reay Wilson]], appointed four months after the ruling. Nearly 80 years later, on October 8, 2009, the Senate voted to make the five the first "honorary senators".<ref name=cbc>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/story/2009/10/10/calgary-famous-five-honourary-senators.html |title='Famous 5' named honorary senators |work=[[CBC News]] |publisher=CBC.ca |date=October 10, 2009 |accessdate=May 10, 2013}}</ref><ref name=hansard>{{cite web|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/common/..%5C40%5C2%5Cparlbus%5Cchambus%5Csenate/deb-E/059db_2009-10-08-e.htm?Language=E&Parl=40&Ses=2#53|title=Senate of Canada – Debates|first=Senate of|last=Canada|publisher=}}</ref> The achievement of personhood for women had been a monumental change which gave more power to women.
Some might well question the overall significance of the decision, noting that by the 1920s the Senate of Canada was a largely powerless body. The more powerful [[House of Commons of Canada]] had elected its first female member ([[Agnes Macphail]]) in 1921, well before the Persons Case. However, the precedent did establish the principle that women could hold any political office in Canada. Moreover, the Five clearly did devote their energies to increasing women's participation on legislative bodies with greater power: three had been members of the [[Legislative Assembly of Alberta|Alberta legislature]]. The controversy surrounding the women has made commemoration difficult.{{Citation needed|date = August 2012}} The five women were activists in a variety of areas in their pursuit to better the conditions for women and children.
[[Image:KingPersons.jpg|thumb|left|Unveiling of a plaque commemorating the Famous Five, June 11, 1938. (Front row, L–R): Muir Edwards, daughter-in-law of [[Henrietta Edwards|Henrietta Muir Edwards]]; J. C. ===Opinions on the Famous Five=== Opinions on the Famous Five vary considerably. Many laud them as trailblazers for women. Others are disturbed by the opinions of some of the women on other issues, such as opposition to non-white immigration and their successful campaigns to have [[eugenics]] legislation introduced in Canadian provinces, which resulted in the sterilization of thousands of those deemed "mentally deficient" or "insane" in Alberta and elsewhere.<ref>http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/eugenics-keeping-canada-sane-feature/</ref> Emily Murphy was not shy with her opinions and her outspoken nature had a tendency to give her a negative reputation. She wrote letters of her opinions to police chiefs, government officials, social service agencies and judicial officials about the extent of drug traffic and possible cures. Nellie McClung was known as the most memorable and popular of the famous five. Her causes included women's right to vote, prohibition, women in the church and women in public life.<ref name=Millar/> Henrietta Muir Edwards was described as "tenacious" with her work with prohibition.<ref name=MacEwan/>
The five women were activists in a variety of areas in their pursuit to better the conditions for women and children. Emily Murphy dealt with single mothers and issues of child support, child welfare, and adoption by lobbying for women's rights.<ref name = Sharpe>{{cite book| first=Robert J.| last=Sharpe| title=The Persons Case: The Origins and Legacy of the Fight for Legal Personhood| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HOwC1vcGgcEC&pg=PA16&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4| isbn=978-0802096289| year=2007| publisher=[[University of Toronto Press]]}}</ref> Nellie McClung favoured free medical and dental treatment for school children as well as mothers' allowances and better property rights for women. She was open to divorce and birth control but opposed the sale and use of liquor. Louise McKinney believed strongly in the "evils of alcohol" and pushed to enact prohibition measures. She advocated excluding cigarettes from parcels sent to soldiers in World War I in 1917. She supported reasonable measures for social welfare and health as well as introducing bills intended to make prohibition more effective, to improve the lot of immigrants and bring better security to widows. She was responsible for the introduction of a motion which led to the [[Dower Act]]. Irene Parlby in her position as cabinet minister in Alberta pursued these goals expressed by McKinney. Henrietta Edwards worked with property law and sought to protect women and children.<ref name=Millar/>
===Commemorations=== The Famous Five have been commemorated with individual and group plaques in the [[Centre Block#Senate foyer|foyer]] and antechamber of Canada's Senate, and two identical sculptures by Canadian artist [[Barbara Paterson]], one on [[Parliament Hill]] in [[Ottawa]], the other at the [[Olympic Plaza (Calgary)|Olympic Plaza]] in [[Calgary]]. The sculpture on Parliament Hill was unveiled on October 18, 2000, in a public ceremony that included [[French language in Canada|French]] and [[Canadian English|English]] singers, [[Inuit]] dancers, and speeches by [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]] [[Adrienne Clarkson]] and [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Jean Chrétien]]. A sculpture of the Famous Five by sculptor Helen Granger Young stands on the grounds of the Manitoba Legislature in Winnipeg. Commissioned by the Nellie McClung Foundation, it was unveiled at a ceremony on June 18, 2010.
The City of [[Edmonton]] has named one park in its River Valley Parks System after each of the "Famous Five".<ref name="edmonton">{{cite web| title=Alphabetical Park Listing| url=http://www.edmonton.ca/attractions_recreation/parks_rivervalley/alphabetical-park-listing.aspx| publisher=City of Edmonton| date=May 14, 2012| accessdate=May 14, 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127115516/http://edmonton.ca/attractions_recreation/parks_rivervalley/alphabetical-park-listing.aspx| archivedate=November 27, 2012| df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Murphy had many accomplishments, such as becoming the first president of the Federated Women's Institute of Canada, vice-president of [[National Council of Women]] of Canada, president of [[Canadian Women's Press Club]], director of the Canadian Council of Child Welfare, vice-president of the Canadian Association of Child Protection, first president of the Women's Canadian Club of Edmonton and vice-president of the Social Service Council of Canada. Emily Murphy also received many honours for her life's work including being decorated by King [[George V]] to be a Lady of Grace of the [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|Order of St. John of Jerusalem]].
Irene Parlby was honoured in 1935 at spring convocation at the [[University of Alberta]] with an honorary LL.D. degree. Tributes in honour of Henrietta Edwards can be found on a plaque in the Senate Chamber in Ottawa and another in the post office in Fort Macleod. Nellie McClung spoke in Calgary after Edwards' passing and spoke of Edwards, "who for 40 years was convener of laws for the National Council of Women" should not be forgotten.<ref name="MacEwan" />
Along with [[Thérèse Casgrain]], the Five were commemorated in the 2001 [[Journey Series (banknotes)|Journey Series]] of Canada's [[Canadian fifty-dollar bill|fifty-dollar bill]].<ref name=Brennan/> In December 2011, the [[Bank of Canada]] announced that the Famous Five would not appear on the redesigned $50 [[Frontier Series]] banknote that it issued in 2012.<ref name="50dollars">{{cite news| title=Should the new $50 bill show an Arctic research boat instead of the Famous Five?| url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/yourcommunity/2011/12/should-the-new-50-bill-show-an-arctic-research-boat-instead-of-the-famous-five.html| work=CBC News| date=December 7, 2011| publisher=cbc.ca| accessdate=May 17, 2013}}</ref>
The achievement of personhood for women had been a monumental change which gave more power to women. To honour the Five and continue to involve women in leadership roles in Canada, Frances Wright and others established the non-profit Famous Five Foundation on October 18, 1996, the 70th anniversary of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council's decision.<ref name="5foundation">{{cite web| url=http://www.famous5.ca/index.php/about-us/about-us| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121225022456/http://www.famous5.ca/index.php/about-us/about-us| dead-url=yes| archive-date=December 25, 2012| title=About Us| publisher=Famous 5 Foundation| date=| accessdate=May 17, 2013}}</ref>

{{Twelvers|collapsed=1}} '''The Twelve Imams''' are the spiritual and political successors to the [[Islam]]ic prophet [[Muhammad]] in the [[Twelver]] or ''Athnā‘ashariyyah'' branch of [[Shia Islam]], including that of the [[Alawite]] and the [[Alevi]] sects.{{Harvnb|Olsson|Ozdalga|Raudvere|2005|p=65}} According to the [[theology of Twelvers]], also the Twelve Imams are exemplary human individuals who not only rule over the community with justice, but also are able to keep and interpret ''[[sharia]]'' and the [[Esoteric interpretation of the Quran|esoteric meaning of the Quran]]. Muhammad and Imams' [[Sunnah|words and deeds]] are a guide and model for the community to follow; as a result, they must be free from error and sin (known as ''[[ismah]]'', or infallibility) and must be chosen by divine decree, or ''[[Nass (Islam)|nass]]'', through the Prophet.{{Harvnb|Tabataba'i|1977|p=10}}{{Harvnb|Momen|1985|p=174}}[[File:Twelvers1 copy copy.png|thumb|Calligraphic representation of the Twelve Imams along with that of the Prophet Muhammad.]] ==The belief of Imamah== {{main|Imamate (Twelver doctrine)}} It is believed in [[Twelver]] [[Shia Islam]] that [[Aql (Shiasm)|‘aql]], divine wisdom, is the source of the souls of the Prophets and Imams and gives them esoteric knowledge called ''[[Hikmah]]'' and that their sufferings are a means of divine grace to their devotees.{{Harvnb|Tabataba'i|1977|p=15}}{{Harvnb|Corbin|2014|pp=45–51}} Although the Imam is not the recipient of a [[wahy|divine revelation]], he has a close relationship with [[Allah|God]], through which God guides him, and the Imam in turn guides the people. The Imams are also guided by secret texts in their possession, such as [[Al-Jafr (book)|al-Jafr]] and [[al-Jamia]]. [[Imamate]], or belief, in the divine guide is a fundamental belief in the Twelver Shia doctrine and is based on the concept that God would not leave humanity without access to divine guidance.{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Encyclopaedia of Islam and the Muslim world; vol.1 | last = Gleave | first = Robert | title=Imamate | publisher = MacMillan | ISBN = 0-02-865604-0}} According to Twelvers, there is at all times an Imam of the era who is the divinely appointed authority on all matters of faith and law in the Muslim community. [[Ali]] was the first of the Twelve Imams, and, in the Twelvers and Sufis' view, the [[Succession to Muhammad|rightful successor to Muhammad]], followed by male [[descendants of Muhammad]] through his daughter [[Fatimah]]. Each Imam was the son of the previous Imam, with the exception of [[Husayn ibn Ali]], who was the brother of [[Hasan ibn Ali]]. The twelfth and final Imam is [[Muhammad al-Mahdi]], who is believed by the Twelvers to be currently alive, and hidden in [[The Occultation#Major Occultation|the Major Occultation]] until he returns to bring justice to the world. It is believed by [[Twelver]] [[Shia]] and [[Alevi]] [[Muslims]] that the Twelve Imams have been foretold in the [[Hadith of the Twelve Successors]]. All of the Imams met unnatural deaths, with the exception of the last Imam, who according to Twelver and Alevi belief, is living in occultation. The Twelve Imams also have a leading role within some [[Sufism|Sufi]] orders and are seen as the spiritual heads of Islam, because most of the [[Silsila]] ''(spiritual chain)'' of Sufi orders lead back to one of the Twelve Imams. ==List of Imams== {|class="wikitable" width="98%" style="background:white;" |- style="border-bottom:3px solid #CCCCFF" ! '''''Theophanes Continuatus''''' ({{lang-el|συνεχισταί Θεοφάνους}}) or '''''Scriptores post Theophanem''''' ({{lang|grc|Οἱ μετὰ Θεοφάνην}}, "those after Theophanes") is the [[Latin]] name commonly applied to a collection of historical writings preserved in the 11th-century Vat. gr. 167 manuscript.<ref name="ODB2061">Kazhdan (1991), p. 2061</ref> Its name derives from its role as the continuation, covering the years 813–961, of the [[chronicle]] of [[Theophanes the Confessor]], which reaches from 285 to 813. The manuscript consists of four distinct works, in style and form very unlike the [[annals|annalistic]] approach of Theophanes.<ref name="ODB">Kazhdan (1991), pp. 2061–2062</ref>
The first work, of four books consists of a series of biographies of the emperors reigning from 813 to 867 (from [[Leo the Armenian]] to [[Michael III]]). As they were commissioned by Emperor [[Constantine VII]] (r. 913–959), they reflect the point of view of the reigning [[Macedonian dynasty]]. The unknown author probably used the same sources as [[Genesios]].<ref name="ODB"/> The second work is known as the ''Vita Basilii'' (Latin for "Life of Basil"), a biography of [[Basil I the Macedonian]] (r. 867–886) written by his grandson Constantine VII probably around 950. The work is essentially a [[panegyric]], praising Basil and his reign while vilifying his predecessor, Michael III.<ref>Kazhdan (1991), pp. 2062, 2180–2181</ref> The third work is a history of the years 886–948, in form and content very close to the history of [[Symeon Logothetes]], and the final section continues it until 961. It was probably written by [[Theodore Daphnopates]], shortly before 963.<ref>Kazhdan (1991), p. 2062</ref>

[[File:The two sons of Francis Manners, St Mary's church, Bottesford (geograph 2736171).jpg|thumb|upright=0.90|alt=Memorial to Henry & Francis Manners in Bottesford|Memorial to Henry and Francis Manners, the heirs to the [[Francis Manners, 6th Earl of Rutland|6th Earl and Countess of Rutland]], whom the Witches of Belvoir were accused of killing]] The '''Witches Belvoir''' were a mother and her two daughters accused of [[witchcraft]] in England in the deaths of two young nobles, Henry (died 1613) and Francis Manners (died 1620), the heirs to [[Francis Manners, 6th Earl of Rutland]], whose seat was at [[Belvoir Castle]] . The mother, Joan Flower, died on the way to her trial, and the two daughters, Margaret and Philippa, were supposed to be hanged in [[Lincoln, Lincolnshire|Lincoln]]. It is said that Phillipa drugged the guards and managed to escape and make her way to Kent where she died after having three children.
==Flowers of Bottesford== Joan, Margaret and Philippa Flowers were "known to be herbal healers" and came from a local family that "had fallen on hard times".<ref name="BBCFramed">{{cite news | title = Witches of Belvoir 'may have been framed' | date = 2013-10-31 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-24748721 | work = BBC | accessdate = 2013-11-01}}</ref> They accepted employment as servants with the [[Francis Manners, 6th Earl of Rutland|6th Earl and Countess of Rutland]], at [[Belvoir Castle]] near [[Grantham, Lincolnshire]], when additional staff were needed for an upcoming visit by [[James VI and I|King James I]].<ref name="BBCFramed"/> But the sisters, and their mother, were unpopular with the other staff, and there were suggestions of theft, and misdemeanors.<ref name="BBCFramed"/> All three were dismissed and only Joan was given a payment of severance amounting to "40 shillings, a bolster (pillow), and a mattress of wool".<ref name="thiswasleics">{{cite news | title = The Witches of Belvoir Castle | date = 2012-11-12 | url = http://www.thiswasleicestershire.co.uk/2012/11/the-witches-of-belvoir-castle.html | work = This Was Leicestershire | accessdate = 2013-11-01}}</ref>
After the sisters were dismissed, the Earl and Countess fell ill, suffering from "vomiting and convulsions".<ref name="thiswasleics"/> Their son and heir, Henry, [[Baron de Ros]],<ref name="bottshist">{{cite web | url = http://www.bottesfordhistory.org.uk/page_id__61_path__0p4p72p.aspx | title = The Bottesford Witches, Introduction | accessdate = 2013-11-01 | last = Bob | first = Sparford | work = Bottesford Living History}}</ref> died, and was buried on 26 September 1613.<ref name="fleming">{{cite book | last1 = Miller | first1 = William E. | title = The Library Chronicle | chapter = Samuel Fleming, Elizabethan Clergyman | volume = XXV | publisher = University of Pennsylvania | year = 1959 | pages = 61–79 | url = https://archive.org/stream/librarychronicle25univ#page/n7/mode/2up | accessdate = 2013-11-01}}</ref> Their younger children, Francis, and daughter [[Katherine Villiers, Duchess of Buckingham|Katherine]], suffered similarly <ref name="bygone"/> and Francis died 7 March 1620. The deaths of the two boys left the Earl without a male heir and Earldom passed to his brother after his own death in 1632.<ref name="burke">{{cite book |title= [[Burke's Peerage|Burke's Peerage, Baronetage & Knighthood]]|publisher=Burke's Peerage & Gentry |editor= Mosley, Charles |editorlink= Charles Mosley (genealogist) |edition=107 |year= 2003 |page= 3447 |ref=Burke |isbn=0-9711966-2-1}}</ref>
==Charge of witchcraft== Three years after Henry's death, on 16 July 1616, nine women were hanged as witches in [[Leicestershire]] for having bewitched a young boy and, in charges similar to those in the Flowers' case, were said to have kept cats as familiars.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Briscoe | first1 = J. Potter | last2 = Andrews (Editor) | first2 = William | title = Bygone Leicestershire | chapter = Witchcraft In Leicestershire | publisher = F. Murray, W. Andrews & co., Simpkin, Marshall & Hamilton, Kent, & co. | location = Leicestershire, Hull & London | year = 1892 | pages = 126–130 | url = https://archive.org/stream/bygoneleicesters00andriala#page/n7/mode/2up | accessdate = 2013-11-01}}</ref> But it was to be five years after the Flowers were dismissed from [[Belvoir Castle]], and following the death of their second son, Francis,<ref name="histwitch">{{cite book | last1 = Notestein | first1 = Wallace | title = A History of Witchcraft in England from 1558 to 1718 | publisher = American Historical Association | year = 1911 | location = Washington | pages = 133 | url = https://archive.org/stream/ahistorywitchcr00notegoog#page/n6/mode/2up | accessdate = 2013-11-01}}</ref> that the [[Francis Manners, 6th Earl of Rutland|Rutlands]] had the Flowers arrested, before Christmas of 1618.<ref name="bygone">{{cite book | last1 = Andrews (Editor) | first1 = William | title = Bygone Leicestershire | publisher = F. Murray, W. Andrews & co., Simpkin, Marshall & Hamilton, Kent, & co. | location = Leicestershire, Hull & London | year = 1892 | pages = 91–92 | url = https://archive.org/stream/bygoneleicesters00andriala#page/n7/mode/2up | accessdate = 2013-11-01}}</ref> After initial examinations, in February 1619,<ref name="histwitch"/> by the [[Francis Manners, 6th Earl of Rutland|Earl of Rutland]], Hon. [[Robert Bertie, 1st Earl of Lindsey|Robert Bertie, Lord Willoughby de Eresby]], Sir George Manners, Sir William Pelham, Sir Henry Hastings, clergyman Samuel Fleming and others,<ref name="fleming"/> the women were to be taken to [[Lincoln, Lincolnshire|Lincoln]] [[gaol]].<ref name="bookdays"/>
When arrested Joan Flower professed her innocence. She was not known to be a Church-goer, but at [[Ancaster, Lincolnshire|Ancaster]], en route to the prison at [[Lincoln, England|Lincoln]],<ref name="bygone"/> she asked for bread as a substitute for the Eucharist.<ref name="BormanRev">{{cite news | first = Bella | last = Bathurst | title = Witches: A Tale of Sorcery, Scandal and Seduction by Tracy Borman – review | date = 2013-08-25 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/aug/25/witches-sorcery-scandal-borman-review | work = The Guardian | accessdate = 2013-11-01}}</ref> She claimed that something so blessed could not be consumed by a witch but she was to choke and die, after the first bite.<ref name="BormanRev"/>
At Lincoln, Margaret was to accuse her mother of witchcraft, while Phillipa admitted to witchcraft on behalf of herself, Margaret and Joan.<ref name="fleming"/> The sisters said they had entered into communion with [[familiar spirit]]s that had assisted them with their schemes. The mother's familiar was a cat named ''Rutterkin''.<ref name="bookdays">{{cite book | last1 = Chambers | first1 = Robert | title = The Book Of Days | chapter = March 11th | year = 1869 | url = http://www.thebookofdays.com/months/march/11.htm | accessdate = 2013-11-01}}</ref> The women admitted that they stole the glove of Lord Ros and gave it to their mother, who had dipped it in boiling water, stroked it along Rutterkin's back, and pricked it.<ref name="bookdays"/> Combined with some incantations this supposedly caused Lord Ros to become ill and die. An attempt to harm [[Katherine Villiers, Duchess of Buckingham|Lady Katherine]], the Earl's daughter, had failed when it was found that ''Rutterkin'' had no power over her. The women had also taken some feathers from the quilt of Rutland's bed and a pair of gloves. By boiling these in water mixed with blood they cast spells to prevent the Earl and Countess from having any more children.<ref name="bookdays"/> Both women admitted to experiencing visions of devils and that their familiar spirits visited them and sucked at their bodies.<ref name="bookdays"/>
==Others accused== [[File:Threewitches.jpg|right|250px|thumb|left|A contemporary sketch of three other women accused: Anne Baker, Joan Willimot & Ellen Greene.]] During the examination, they revealed the names of other women who had aided them: Anne Baker of [[Bottesford, Leicestershire|Bottesford]]; Joan Willimot of [[Goadby, Leicestershire|Goadby]]; and Ellen Greene of [[Stathern]].<ref name="bottshist2">{{cite web | url = http://www.bottesfordhistory.org.uk/page_id__62_path__0p2p46p.aspx | title = The Bottesford Witches, The Wonderful Discovery of the Witchcrafts of Joan, Margaret and Phillipa Flower | accessdate = 2013-11-01 | last = Bob | first = Sparford | work = Bottesford Living History}}</ref>
All three women were taken for examination and revealed that they too had visions and consorted with familiar spirits.<ref name="bottshist2"/> Willimott said her familiar was called ''Pretty'' and had been blown into her mouth by her former master in the form of a fairy, later reappearing in the form of a woman who asked her to give up her soul. Willimott testified more as a [[Cunning folk in Britain|cunning woman]] than a witch, and insisted ''Pretty'' only helped her to inquire about the health of people she had attempted to heal:
{{quote|She never hurt any body, but did help divers persons that were stricken or fore-spoken (bewitched): and that her Spirit came weekly to her, and would tell of divers persons that were stricken and fore-spoken: and she saith that the use which she had of the Spirit, was to know those did which she had undertaken to amend and she did help them by certain prayers which she used.<ref name="bottshist2"/>}}
Greene claimed that she had accompanied Willimot into a wood where she said Willimot had conjured up two spirits in the form of a kitten and a "moldewarp" ([[mole (animal)|mole]]) which had climbed on her shoulders and sucked at her ears. Greene sent these familiars to kill a man and woman with whom she had argued and both died within a fortnight. Baker also confessed to possessing a familiar in the form of a white dog, but most of her testimony concerned the visions she had witnessed.
==Aftermath and legacy== [[File:Inscription on Tomb of 6th Earl of Rutland.jpg|thumb|250px|alt=Images of memorial text at Bottesford|'died in their infancy by wicked practises and sorcerye' – part of the memorial at [[Bottesford, Leicestershire|Bottesford]]]] Margaret and Philippa Flowers were tried before [[Sir Henry Hobart, 1st Baronet|Henry Hobart]], Lord Chief Justice of the Common Pleas, and [[Edward Bromley]], a [[Exchequer of Pleas|Baron of the Exchequer]], and found guilty.<ref name="fleming"/> and Margaret was hung at [[Lincoln castle]] on 11 March 1619.<ref name="BBCFramed"/>
Later that year a ballad, ''Damnable Practises of Three Lincolnshire Witches Joane Flower and Her Two Daughters'', printed by 'G. Eld for John Barnes' appeared.<ref name="fleming"/>
The Earl and Countess remained so convinced that their son had been killed by the effects of witchcraft that they had it inscribed on their monument at [[Bottesford, Leicestershire|Bottesford]] church. It reads, in part:
{{quote|In 1608 he married ye lady Cecila Hungerford, daughter to ye Honorable Knight Sir John Tufton, by whom he had two sons, both of which died in their infancy by wicked practises and sorcerye<ref name="bottshist"/>}}
In 1953, Hilda Lewis published a historical romance, ''The Witch and the Priest'', which consists of a series of conversations between Samuel Fleming, the clergyman who oversaw the Flowers' examinations, and the ghost of Joan Flower.<ref name="fleming"/>
In 2013, historian Tracey Borman suggested that the Flowers women may have been framed by a favourite of [[James VI and I|King James I]], the [[Lincolnshire]] born George Villiers, who was created [[George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham|Duke of Buckingham]] in 1623.<ref name="BBCFramed"/> Watson's theory is that Villiers had plans to marry the [[Francis Manners, 6th Earl of Rutland|Rutland's]] daughter [[Katherine Villiers, Duchess of Buckingham|Katherine]] and, with her two brothers dead, inherit the title.<ref name="BBCFramed"/> Watson argues 'he had them poisoned – then framed Joan Flower and her two daughters as witches to create a smokescreen to cover up his own guilt'.<ref name="BBCFramed"/> After the execution of the Flowers sisters, [[George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham|Villiers]] went on to marry the [[Francis Manners, 6th Earl of Rutland|Rutland's]] sole heir [[Katherine Villiers, Duchess of Buckingham|Katherine]] on 16 May 1620.<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Manners, Francis|volume=36|pages=49–50}}</ref>
